description:
I am so glad that The Homestead is now my local neighborhood bar! They ambiance is super chill and the bartenders are very friendly, there is often some talent visiting the bar as well. 

The beer prices are super reasonable and they have a great selection of draft beers. The cocktails are very well made as well, which I really appreciate. 

The jukebox is super affordable with a great music selection as well.
author: Stephanie A.

description:
I just hate it when I order a Guinness and two minutes later, the beer is in front of you.

That's not how you pull a pint.  I'm glad The Homestead knows how.

Yes it's a borderline dive bar, but hey...it's been around forever, so they're exempt from any criticism that any hipster can dole out.

Come here not to impress, but come here to chill and stay low key.
author: Ron L.

description: Super chill neighborhood bar. Very friendly beer prices too. Way nicer to visit during weekdays than weekends since it's a lot less crowded and you can really enjoy the ambiance.
author: Novalina N.

description:
Let's be honest. "Happening" neighborhood bars in the West Bay are a dime a dozen these days, and the Homestead is no exception.

Yes, the venue has a rustic, saloon-like feel to it. Yes, there are antiquish touches throughout. Yes, it tries to be down-home and casual enough so that you can feel free to throw your peanut shells onto the floor instead of cleaning up after yourself like a civilized human being like your Momma taught you to. Yes, the prices and service are decent, but at the end of the day it's the same gentrified, borderline self-absorbed crowd you'll see anywhere in the West Bay.

So what's so special about it? Cue the sound of crickets chirping. It's simply a neighborhood bar. And that's about it. Just because it's located in a supposedly "hot" neighborhood, let alone the West Bay, doesn't mean it's the best thing since sliced bread.
author: Vincent L.

description:
Classier than a dive bar, but casual and feels like home.  Get the peanuts, throw the shells on the floor. Admire the gorgeous deco ceiling and velvet nudie art.  Enjoy a nicely made cocktail for a reasonable price, and on weekends, there is often a dj.

It can be quite loud later in the night, but I've rarely not been able to find a seat,
author: Rachel R.

description:
Rude bartender, woman in her 30s hard on the eyes, can't make a hot toddy. 

Techie scum tends to reserve the back room, half the place is ruined based on that.
author: Kevin M.

description:
EXTREMELY dog friendly place.  It's got a nice feel to it, vintage decorations, and they make some really good cocktails.  If you're a beer lover, they've got some good ones on tap at really reasonable prices.

But that's not fully why I go there.  I go there because the staff and regulars from the neighborhood are fantastic people.  I also get to bring my dog and she gets TONS of love.  Plus they're open earlier (2pm) and sometimes I act like an old person and go home early on Friday nights.
author: Christopher J.

description:
I came here after work with friends and had a Moscow mule. I've had better drinks but I LOVED the fact that this place is dog friendly!

Come here if you want a chill place to grab drinks, peanuts and hang with your dog! Cool neighborhood spot.
author: Kelly F.

description: A good bar that serves old speckled hen and has a good homey feel (hence the name?). Also I'm super into all these pictures of dogs at the bar. They should always have dogs at all bars. Resident dogs.
author: Misha T.

description:
You eat peanuts and throw the shells on the floor. Interesting concept, but dont wear open toed shoes!

Low key spot to grab drinks in the mission. I love that you can bring dogs here as well! May have to go back and bring my little babe :)
author: Claire W.

description:
Tecate on tap for $3 a pint, how can you beat that?

And the bar has been around since 1902, it's like drinking in a saloon in the Wild West!
author: Simon C.

description: Fun, relaxed bartenders who really know their cocktails and are always nice to our puppy! Great atmosphere as well.
author: E. S.

description:
This is exactly what a good dive bar should be.  No frills, just a bar, some tables, beer and shots. They do have a small cocktail menu on the wall but that's not what this place is about. In the middle of the neighborhood, looks like an old house turned bar. Doesn't get any better than this. The bartenders were cool too. 

Great place and dog friendly too
author: Scott M.

description: I love this place.  not super divey but not fancy either.  drinks are great and super strong.  you get as many free peanuts as ya want and get to throw shells all over the place and all over your friends. fun!!
author: vlad k.

description:
We came to this bar because it was recommended by my sister, who is a drinker. I only socialize and drink, but growing up with my sister, she always knew her alcohol, and she always has good taste in wine liquor. So, we wanted to take my brother here because they wanted to try some specialty beers that they have. Don't ask me cuz I'm not familiar with any kind of alcohol or beer. Only one which is a little too strong for me unless it's a light beer Guinness. I will drink it now the beer. I do like Japanese Sapporo. I'm not sure what the other name is for the other Japanese beer, but I also like Belgian beer which is Stella. It's light. It's crisp. They also had a Christmas blend beer which I didn't get to taste, but I heard that my sister in law and brother liked it had a little cinnamon and some other spices little flavors in it. They enjoyed the beers that they ordered: Hammerstein Guinness, some Christmas blend, and Stella beer.
Oh one more thing there was a fireplace and we SAT right next to it so we were very warm and cozy, and they also give you a basket of peanuts which you can  conversating while  drinking your beer.  
And above me had they had alcohol glass case and a cross from me was a naked portrait of a woman with Tatas that the men would love. lol
Thanks for reading my review. ~Liz~ :)
author: Lizzie G.

description: One out of probably a handful of bars in SF that know how to make an old fashioned. Really nice atmosphere here as well, more classy people instead of drunk college kids.
author: Yevgeniy V.

description: Homestead is such a nice bar. The decor is lovely and I love the paintings on the wall. It was pretty busy on a Saturday night, but we didn't have to wait too long for our drinks. I just went with a good old Corpse Reviver No. 2. We were able to sit at the bench, facing the bar. It made for some good people watching. The bar is super dog friendly. I'll certainly come back!
author: Vanessa S.

description:
Despite the rain pouring down outside, this place was pretty packed for a Friday  night.

It's definitely a cool/chill/cozy bar to hit on a rainy night. I loved the wood-burning stove in the corner which definitely kept the place nice and cozy.

Bar staff was cool. Drinks aren't the cheapest here but it's nice to check out regardless. Love the vintage vibe.
author: Carol M.

description: Cool bar, not that expensive. Coming back again for some beers. The beef jerky was really good and a piece was just a dollar.
author: Bimarsh S.

description: I live in the area so I decided to try this place with my girlfriend, went in for a beer but was never acknowledged, there was only one bartender so how were we ever going to get a drink if this bartender couldn't see us right in front of him, it's like we were ghost . Didn't want to be a jerk by signaling my hand around . But it sucked that even tho we were one foot away from his face he still couldn't ask if we wanted anything and come on a Tuesday night it's not busy or anything ended up just leaving bc it was completely dumb to come to a bar and sit there like idiots with no drinks in our hands :/  never coming here again waste of my time . Walk over to the Alamo theater there's a bar inside and the bartenders there are really nice and attentive.
author: Rafa C.

description: Okay so I like the staff the bar is chill.  I'm a little pissed that I just read someone reserved the back room for $20.  They made me pay $100 and then there was only one table.  I told them I had an arts and craft thing so it wasn't really that nicely set up I thought there would be a ton of seating and tables and it was like one big table and the rest of the room was empty.  It also looked like they used the room for storage.  I wouldn't have minded paying $20 but $100 was really a lot for me.  I would go back for drinks but not ever pay to reserve the back as it's really better for drinking only.
author: Nirea S.

description: Such a great, chill bar. Good drinks, fun decor, jukebox. Perfect go-to if you live in the area. We've rented-out the back room a couple times, most recently for our wedding afterparty. We reserved and followed-up with Deb, who was super helpful in the time leading-up when our friends reached-out about details. We had such a fun time the night-of. Perfect place to stumble after our event at Stable Cafe. Had some snacks and tunes back there, no problem. And you have to love that the rental fee goes to a good cause. The staff that night was not super-friendly... but our group had been partying for a while, so we'll just chalk that up to mis-march of energy and enthusiasm. We're still glad they were a part of our big day.
author: Jen H.

description: Total local bar in the mission district of SF. This place felt like a speakeasy (I think it may have been one at one point). They featured all California beers on tap. I ended up trying an Anchorage on recommendation from our host. They also let you eat peanuts from the shell and drop them on the floor! This place was so fun. Right before we left the DJ started to set up, and he began to play all this old time jazz music. It was really unique!
author: Celeste G.

description:
I love this bar I can't believe I never knew it existed! Apparently its more of a Mission locals bar and I can for sure see that. I'm in the Mission all the time but I mostly just hang around Valencia. 

Came here after the free standup show at Rite Spot on Monday and got totally shitfaced with my friends. At one point we stopped at looked at our table and there was about 30 glasses at our table. Ughhhhh. Monday night partying, never again. I asked the bartender for four of their cheapest vodka shots and the bill was only $12 wtf?! There is no way it could've been that cheap! I thought it would be $20 at least. We had a bunch of cocktails as well that were also very reasonably priced. 

Good crowd for a Monday night. Nice bartender redeeming my bad bartender experience at Blondie's earlier thank goodness.
author: Tiffany V.

description: Based on some of the reviews I read I guess if you aren't a regular here then don't bother coming in. Came in here with my boyfriend on a Wednesday night, while conveniently getting some laundry done next door, for a beer and cocktail. We walked in and after walking back and forth to get the bartenders attention we found two seats. The bartender walked past us several times but refused to even look at us. There were two guys next to us and he asked them if they wanted another beer but not once glanced over at us. Then another lady walked in and sat down and not a minute passed by when he took her order and served her right away. Then he continued to walk by us and not even glance over at us. I have been living in this area for 21 years and I really wanted to like the bar hoping it would become a regular spot for us but I guess the bartender ruined that for us. Judging by some of the other reviews I read this might be the same guy who has ignored other people he has curly hair and somewhat of a full beard. Seriously avoid him. You're better off walking over a couple blocks to the bar inside the Alamo theater on mission where the bartenders actually notice and care about you.
author: Sandra C.

description: Such a great neighborhood bar where dogs are allowed to hang out. So casual and kick back. Good for groups of friends that are bar hopping and need a place to chill for an hour before heading out to the next bar.
author: Theresa D.

description: A very fun bar I enjoyed the atmosphere drinks and the friendly Pup running around the bar
author: chad C.

description: Great place to get a drink after work!  Busy, but I've always been able to find a place to sit. Creative cocktails that have yet to disappoint.
author: Maria M.

description: Small, intimate and cozy! This is a great place to sit by a fire, have a special cocktail for a good price and maybe watch some sports. I appreciate the sexy nude art/ western theme. You can't go wrong with $1 peanuts to crack open and toss on the floor!!!
author: Kristin D.

description:
This is the kind of bar I would have frequented in New Orleans. This is a good thing. While, yes, the hipster-to-normal-person ration was violently askew, ask yourself, "Self: where are you?" Get the answer. Go back to doing what you were doing.

Now, with such a popular venue, it may be difficult to find a place to rest your tired legs. If so, simply do what I did: growl at the fellows lazing about four seats (2 guys, 4 seats; is this a new internet meme?) at the bar until they get uncomfortable (read: scared) and they leave. Problem solved. Even though the bar tends to fall on the crowded side of the aisle, it's not so loud that you can't spend some quality time catching up with one of your best friends in the world.

I found the bartender to be pretty cool. He wasn't overly chatty but he was attentive, polite and d@mn good at his job. I started the evening with a Blood & Sand -- because they make me feel fancybroody. This one was expertly made. The scotch was the star of the show but the liqueur brightened it up enough to make it dangerously drinkable. The vermouth added to the aromatic quality of the drink and the blood orange just makes it look cool. After a couple of those, I decided to switch to beer because I had to work in the morning and calling in sick wasn't an option. But besides the skill behind the bar, cool vibe and relaxed scene, my favorite element of The Homestead is the Scooby Doo quality. And if you get the reference (and it should come naturally and quickly), we need to be friends. Like, now.
author: Johnny T.

description:
Homestead is great for cocktails made by hot female bartenders.  Fairly certain I attempted to leave my number on a receipt for one of them, yet I could have fabricated that memory.  $10 is a bit steep for a sazerac in my humble opinion, but it's really the eye candy you pay extra for.  At risk of sounding extra creepy, seamless transition to crowdedness:

On a Friday night here, one can only equate trying to buy a drink to feeling like Michelle Williams amongst Destiny's Child getting wildly whipped across the ocean desperately searching for help in their Survivor music video.  

But on a good note they do have peanuts.
author: Amber D.

description:
Off the beaten Mission path and thoroughly charming, this feels like a small town saloon...full of hipsters, of course. We stopped in for a glass of wine before hitting up Mission Bowling Club (though cocktails are more the thing here). It seems that every seat is a seat right at the bar; an intimate drinking experience, for sure. I relished the feeling of being far away from the Valencia strip, watched the resident bar dog milling about, and tried not to ask any stupid questions to the predictably too-cool bartender, with his old-timey cash register. 

If the Mission is too 'sceney' for you, but you still need a drink, head to Homestead for a low-key, antique-ified refuge, just a few block away.
author: Nique F.

description: Awesome framed nudes. Pressed tin ceiling. Wallpaper. Wood stove. Piano. All the accoutrements of a cozy Victorian parlor.
author: Patrick S.

description:
Friendly neighborhood bar with awesome liquor and nice drinks. Always a spot to sit and hang with your group. The bartenders are down to chat, which is so appreciated when you're out having fun. Nice big windows during the day. Fun cocktail menu too. 

Dogs are allowed!
author: Wendy K.

description:
Overall vibe of Homestead can be summed up in one word, stylish. From the decor to the ceiling everything had a classy vibe without being too pretentious. The drinks are strong but could use some balance. I felt the corpse reviver was too sour and needed to be mixed more. 

Overall Thoughts

A cool, stylish atmosphere that serves good drinks at a reasonable price
author: Eddie W.

description: Nice place for a drink and some peanuts. Nothing exceptional. Get's the job done.
author: Alex C.

description: Dependable bar and perfect go-to with friends. I've been going for years and this place has become more sentimental over the years. There is a wide selection of drinks from cheap to spendy and the bar tenders are on your side, don't ever forget that. Let's ensure this place remains a historic landmark to protect it from the hands of greedy condo developers and city officials. Cheers!
author: Brian J.

description:
On a laid back Friday night with friends, there's nothing better than rolling into a bar and discovering it's exactly the place you want to be.

We ambled up at 9pm, pleased that it was on a quiet street and there wasn't a line out the door. I told the bouncer that I was 101 years old, but he checked my ID anyway (and said I looked good for my age). Amazingly, it wasn't too crowded, and we managed to snag a table right next to the upright piano, which was serving as a drink-stand. It reportedly gets its keys tickled every so often, so I didn't feel too bad for it.

Homestead has a great collection of beers, including big bottles of Belgian blondes, and they make fantastic mixed drinks. For $1 you can tuck into a deep bowl of peanuts, smoky and salty. Cracking them open while chatting with friends has to be one of the most satisfying bar activities, aside from petting the wayward pooch that makes its way under your table and allows you to scratch it behind the ears.

There's something uniquely comforting about the luxurious velvet drapes, beautiful wallpaper, antique tin roof and paintings of nudes; it brings class to a bar that would otherwise be a dive. Said my friend, "Would it be porn if those were photos instead of paintings? Such a fine line..." Beware, as the back room is reserved and you may get booted; otherwise, the crowd is fun and friendly. It's not hard to get a drink, even when the bar does get crowded (at around 10:30pm), and there's a warmth in this Homestead that is hard to beat on those cold SF nights!
author: Ray J.

description: The ambiance is warm and welcoming, but what truly makes or breaks a bar is the Bartender.Stopped in after lunch to check the place out. Brandon our bartender was everything a good tender should be: fast, friendly and very knowledgeable about their cocktail list. I too am a bartender, so my order was straight forward and easy: an Underberg and a cider. Brandon didn't blink an eye, no attitude, just served it up with a smile. As younger people came through the door they had questions about the various "craft" cocktails and their ingredients; once again Brandon answered and served all with the same friendly efficiency. I"ll go again, if just to see if all their bartenders are that good.
author: Lee P.

description: Rustic wood and tin decor and a wooden bar make for the feeling of an old neighborhood parlor.  Good selection of whiskey, and that feels most appropriate here!
author: Brian G.

description: An ok place to hang out for a beer or two, but not necessarily my kind of bar. I assume it is cool for large groups of students.
author: Hildegunn N.

description:
The Homestead is a solid place. It doesn't stand out in any particular way though.

The decor is cool and divey. What you'd expect for a bar in this area. Oil paintings of buxom women adorn the walls, and the big bar is beautiful.

There just isn't any reason to really seek this place out. If you live in the area or hang out in the Mission a lot and are looking for something new - stop in and enjoy The Homestead. It won't let you down, but you won't be surprised either.
author: Dalton C.

description:
I lived in this neighbourhood in the late 90's before moving to Australia (still there). Hence my last (and very regular) patronage of this bar was as Dylan's, the previous tenant. My overall perspective is that it still has a nice low key vibe - a local spot, not attempting to draw the bridge and tunnel masses. 

I'm surprised no locals have identified one of the great benefits of the location: right next door to the Coin-Op laundromat! Laundry day was the perfect excuse to put back a couple pints, then go try to fold your laundry buzzed...

I've only passed through once as Homestead, for one quick pint. Seems to have had a face lift (Dylan's wasn't run down, but didn't try too hard either), and the reports of sometimes too-cool-for-themselves bar tenders are a little discouraging - they had big shoes to fill with the professional bar staff at Dylan's. However, seems to have the right vibe for a decent local, and I'm sure I'd still be drinking there if I was still a local!
author: Lange J.

description:
Homestead is a great place to duck into when traipsing through the Mission. Close to Southern Pacific (seriously, 30 seconds), to boot.

They have some interesting cocktails, but really, we go just for sitting and drinking. The decor is awesome--a friend may have told the bartender at one point, "This place smells like old wood." He's not wrong. 

Also, they have $1 pickles. Can't be mad about that.

The good: good amount of space and tables.
The bad: flies hang out in the middle of the bar, which I can't quite understand.
author: Amanda B.

description:
Ok, look. 

I can bring my dog in here and get a $4 Michelada. There are free peanuts at the bar and discarded peanut shells on the door. It's open whenever you need it. What could possibly be bad?
author: Allison S.

description:
From the people to the peanuts there is nothing plain about this bar.  The old-style saloon type of days have been revamped with a contemporary flair at Homestead.  Grab a drink and try not to get too offended by the slack-jawed faces on each bartender.  They're just doing there job, and a mighty fine one at that.

As for a personal bowl of peanuts and make sure to leave crumbs.
author: Kevin J.

description:
Fireplace in the back corner. Naked female torsos all over the walls. Cozy seating. I'd say all that makes for an inviting bar destination in the wintertime.

Homestead's got a classy vibe without being pretentious, a difficult vibe to achieve. Yes, it's yet another Prohibition-inspired bar, but to me that theme never gets old. Especially since it usually means a top-notch selection of rye and bourbon.

I felt quite at home here. It was intimate, the gin martinis were decent (though not the best) and the crowd was quiet and composed (though to be fair, it was early on in the evening). 

Will definitely go with the Old-Fashioned next time. Homestead, I'll be back.
author: Tiffany W.

description:
Adventures in First Dates at the Homestead
 
Guy 1
He said I'd have the best Manhattan here.  I think he meant the stiffest, cuz that was one strong ass pour.  Nevertheless, I finished it. And the effects were fast.  
Exhibit A:  I'm not a cherry person.  So I said to him: "Would you like to eat my cherry?"  
To which he quizzically tilted his head with a smirk.  
Realizing what I said a drunk second too late, I muttered:
"I mean.................this one"  /points to cherry in the drink
 o_O

      O_o

o_0

He was still smirking. 
"Bartender, she'll have another."
(-___-)
 

Guy 2
On his way towards the restroom, asked me to order him a bourbon, air quotes: "on the rocks".  
I was like "uh...so do you mean....with...out......ice? Your air quotes are throwing me off".  
He turned around to face me, and while walking backwards, threw his arms up again with the air quotes and said "on the rocks", then proceeded to "pow-pow-blow" his gun hands, and put em back into his faux holster.  
The bartender looked at me with pity and said, "I'm makin yours a double.  I hope you parked close". 
/facepalm
 

Guy 3
I think, was actually a girl.
 

I gotta stop coming here.
author: Rho T.

description:
This is a great chill bar in SF. I totally thought I had reviewed it last time I was in SF after I had spent an evening tossing back a multitude of drinks with my Yelp CM cohorts on what turned out to be another in a string of debaucherous nights in The City.

I dig the vibe - It's casual without being divey. Totally a neighborhood watering hole with a decent selection of spirits and favorable beers on tap. A cozy, shotgun setup makes for tight quarters when you have way too many people show up all at once. The staff seems fairly amenable even to large, loud, obnoxious drunken crowds (not to say that our crowd fit that bill, but I'm just imagining so).

I'm sure I'll be back.
author: Don B.

description: Great rustic bar! Great service! Great NUTS! My friends and I alway enjoy visiting!
author: J. Hunter R.

description: Fancy old time feel with boobies on the wall. Got a $10 Homestead Cocktail that was heavy on the pour and small on the glass. The bartender had a sweet beard so you know he has to be good.  I came here because the crosswalk turned before I could run across the street..... Serendipity.
author: Ashley T.

description:
If this were my neighborhood bar, I'd be all over it.  Unfortunately, it is not.

There is nothing too remarkable about The Homestead.  It's a well put together establishment, nicely furnished without rough edges.  Nice for those one-off "grab a quick drink with a friend" moments, but not quite on my map for fun Mission bar hopping.

Simple and straightforward...perfect for the future 30+ year old me. :P
author: Kathleen W.

description:
One word: Nostalgic.

Walking in the joint is like taking a step back in time, golden tin ceilings, period wallpaper, Victorian style frames around the windows, excellent draught selection for the few taps they have, $1 peanuts!!!, extensive bourbon/whisky/rye on back bar.
And the back bar, what a nice piece of wood that is, my friends.
Dog friendly
Awesome art on the walls
It's worth the stop when stopping by the Mission
author: Leonard L.

description:
$27 for a pitcher of ESB?! I couldn't believe my ears when the blonde lady told me the price, AND she said it was a dollar off from the original. Never in San Francisco ( and I visit plenty of bars) have I paid so much money for beer! It's like buying a whole meal with the tip included!


I think it's safe to say I won't be returning there ever again unless your bar wants to buy me a beer or something. Shoot it can even be Tecate for all I care. 

Such an absurd price!
author: Dreski S.

description:
I actually didn't drink anything here. A group of us came on a Friday night. It was extremely crowded so we ended up renting the back room for $50/night, which apparently goes to charity.

3 stars bc it was too crowded to enjoy myself.
author: Margaret R.

description:
When I lived in the mission the Homestead was my favorite neighborhood bar. With a friendly staff and cheap beer ($2 Tecate on tap and cans of PBR) you really can't beat it! 

The Homestead is also one of the rare bars in the mission that accepts credit cards. Yay!
author: Casey S.

description:
Great vibes, and a mean Sazerac. 

My friend Ashley took me here with a group of her pals, and she said it was one of her favorites because it reminded her of the pubs we used to frequent when she lived in London (I'm still there). I'd say The Homestead does one better--it melds the cozy, has-been decadence of London pubs with the warm, can-do feeling of American bars. 

The crowd was eclectic, the noise level was below shout-level, and my scarf almost fell into a dog waterbowl--and I felt at home. At one point, we were led in a group rendition of "happy birthday" for someone whose name I didn't catch. In London, this would be the most embarrassing thing that could happen on a night out. In The Homestead, it was just a bit of fun from which you could seamlessly go back to your conversation.

I don't know if it was the mixing or the ambiance or the lack of ice in my glass, but my Sazerac tasted better there than it ever has in London. Next time, I want to go on a quieter night, and try out the intriguingly-curated jukebox.
author: Alice S.

description: Was here for a birthday party. Cool bar with a great vibe and very good drinks. I wasn't incredibly impressed with their old fashioned, but everything else was great!
author: Zach H.

description:
I went to a going away parting where the hostess rented out the back room. Everything was going great! the room was awesome and appropriate for our private party size. nice large table and seating. Then the bar tender rudely yelled at my 68 yr old mother (who does not drink), "you can't have outside drinks in here lady! come on!" My mother was shocked and apologized as she wasn't made aware and it was only her sparkling water bottle. We quickly packed up and left. I think the situation could have been handled very differently. It made the whole room tense and we all felt very uncomfortable. I asked the hostess (the one who rented the space) if she was aware of a drink minimum in her rental contract or if she was made aware of the fact that you couldn't have outside water? She said when she rented the space all they told her was that she had to keep the door open. which we did. 
The bartender gave us a mean mug as we left and never apologized.
author: Amelia V.

description: Great little place, cocktails are amazing and the decor is old school. Has a really comfortable air.
author: Audrey W.

description: Love this place! One of the oldest bars in San Francisco! Fancy cocktails and a wide range of great spirits. Private back room that can be rented out. Great old timey vibes off the beaten path in the mission.
author: Eric C.

description: Peanuts. Friendly bartenders. Diverse crowd. A tin ceiling + great wallpaper!! I can't believe I've waited this long to check this place out. Arrived at 6 on. Friday night, it was busy but not too crowded, by 7:30 it was packed.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
My new friend Jon A recommended we pop by Homestead post-dinner, and I cannot deny his wisdom in this choice.  Walking up to the bar, I was instantly reminded of the Prince Albert (http://www.yelp.com/biz/prince-albert-london-6), my former local in London. It was absolutely local, neighborhoody, welcoming yet completely unpretentious... something I appreciate more with each city I travel to. 

The same friend ordered a drink for me: a Rye Manhattan. It was both my first rye drink and, shockingly (considering its place in drink iconography), my first Manhattan. I loved it. Perfectly crafted in the hands of a proper bartendress and poured, high, and so full I party-fouled and spilled a bit, it was delicious, strong, and biting in the right way.  About eight of us went to this little spot, but quickly found our place on the bar. We met a tiny rescue puppy in the arms of its owners- this pup is about to travel to Paris- the true "rags to riches" story its new owners proclaimed. 

Perhaps what is most amazing, during my week in San Francisco, a city legendary both for its place in Americana/hippie history and its lore as a tourist locale, is that I was able to discover a welcoming pub with room for this Alabama girl and her friends.  True love at Homestead? Why, yes, indeed.
author: Alden C.

description: Cool bar! The Moscow mules were a little bit weak for my taste, but they were tasty and refreshing. It's a bit difficult to get a seat on a Friday night so keep your eye on the tables, there are a lot of groups that come through and take up a lot of space.
author: Emily G.

description:
God, I love the Homestead. 
Cheap drinks.
Cheap peanuts.
Rarely too crowded.
Friendly staff.
I really wish they had food.
author: Kristin T.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday night for a birthday.  Crappy neighborhood bar. 

Pros:
1) Water - water and cups you can pour for yourself 
2) Beer- about a dozen beers on draft

Cons:
1) Service -  While not very crowded,  bartenders were very lackadaisical, clearly priorizing finishing a conversation with a coworkers over serving the person in front of them 
2) Homeless people in the bar -  homeless people just stroll into the bar. There were at least two homeless people that strolled in
3) Other people at the bar -  had a weird experience where some locals wanted to take seats we were kind of using 


$6 beer is not bad but not a steal. Check somewhere else out. The free water elevates to 2 stars.
author: Ojus P.

description:
It's very pretty and carries no pretense of class or type in its patrons; you don't come to the Homestead to get sloshed or make a scene - folks just come for a drink and company.

Any place that allows dogs and peanut shells on the ground is a huge plus.

Conversation can be difficult as it gets rather crowded and loud on the weekends, but happy hour provides a casual Mission setting for friends to congregate. 

Go for it.
author: Darrell L.

description:
This is good spot for a quick drink.
Nice prices are very low . I want to admit that they have a good decoration.
author: Eric G.

description:
I'd come back just to try more of their extensive rye and bourbon selection.

It was crazy crowded but the bartenders were attentive and quick.  

Worth a visit if you're in the mission.
author: Stephen C.

description:
Loved the feeling like I just walked onto the set of Deadwood or sumpin! They had some wooden tables and chairs and a fireplace going. It was a great bar to celebrate a birthday, sip on some bourbon and hang out with my minority friends! No racism here.

Cool bouncer dude too who's down to play some elementary school games!
author: Yoko H.

description: Really really hate when professionals don't act professionally. Both bartenders acting drunk. Actually denied making a drink saying they don't serve that drink past a certain time but acting like they either did not know how to make the drink or just plain did not feel like making it. Waited way too long for a drink when they were no longer busy. Waited while the bartender took a shot then said bartender actually failed to make us a drink and passed it off to the other bartender. Think he went to bathroom but at least tell the other bartender the drinks so they can make them with out asking again. Just fail.
author: Mike Z.

description:
The homestead, with its poetry above the bar, was the perfect spot to have a guinness and a whiskey with my favorite irishers on the day our the most famed irishman drove out the snakes and gave us all a reason to drink heavily on March 17th.

The bar is all aged wood and nooks and crannies and scarred tables. It's heavy pours and bartenders who can handle a crowd of whatever size. It's a mixed bag of old folks and bright newcomers. f you're looking for a casual pub to grab a brew and a chat in, then the Homestead will work just fine.
author: Kelly S.

description: Went to Homestead on a monday evening - having grown up in London felt at home right away. It's like an old pub in Camden Town, nothing fancy at all, but then they've got Fullers ESB on tap, actual packets of crisps, and there's interesting characters hanging out talking & drinking. Nice cozy atmosphere, (fireplace and a dj spinning old jazz 78's are a plus) - after a couple of pints didn't want to leave!
author: Terry D.

description:
Not what I had expected!  This corner bar is really a neighborhood party spot.  Lots of locals come here and enjoy drinks and peanuts.  The bartender while not to talkative is good and makes sure that your glass is always full.
For my first time here, I thought is was good and will come back....
author: Kenneth G.

description: Dive bar pretending it is not a dive bar. Average drinks and average prices. Better dive bars in the local vicinity.
author: Livia M.

description:
I'm not sure if this place is stupendously awesome, or I was just stupendously drunk... I think, going be the reviews so far, that it's the former. 

I felt more at home in this wee joint than I'd done in multitude of bars in SF. Yeah, they were cool but this place just felt the right amount of sticky, the right amount of comfy, with the right amount of trendy to normal folk ratio. 

I'd popped in here with the one they call Annie L (or GUNS to her friends) for a quiet one after meeting some of her old SF pals at a gallery. The plan was to have one/two, then hit the road. Unfortunately (read fortunately) it seems that all the cool kids (CM-wise) had the same idea. 

Drunken hilarity ensued, culminating in a rendition of a Dylan Thomas poem and a drunken stumble home.... boy, did I feel at home.
author: Chris D.

description: Came here to watch the US-Portugal game: it was packed! Dogs were coming in and out which was a little awkward since it was so crowded (and we were trying to eat).  They have a lot of beer of tap which is nice, but a little pricey for it being semi-divey (but in a good way?)  It's nice though that you can bring in your own food!  Service was just ok, even when the crowd started to thin out (regulars seemed to get a majority of his attention, even when not ordering), there are quite a few homeless people in the area that pop in and hang around inside. Aside form that, the ambiance is good and I dig the decor.
author: Sheena C.

description: Great, friendly bartenders who make a mean Old Fashioned. Beware of the occasional hipster, but other than that it's the perfect neighborhood watering hole and a damn good place to get a Jameson + pickle back after a climbing session. =)
author: Rosavida C.

description: Homestead is worth every penny. We were lucky to go for their best of the year menu and I had the best ribeye I have ever eaten with a perfectly medium rare cook. Our waiter was wonderful! I requested my steak without butter and he knew to ask about another item made with dairy- that's real service and so important to the people who always have to ask about foods with dietary restrictions and there are so few places with staff you can trust to keep an eye out for you! Usually I am disappointed by lacking dairy free desserts BUT they had a melon sorbet and it was wonderful! I have to save one star for just ONE thing- I would really like to see a list of foods that are found locally and where they come from. It's really important to me as a consumer and should be a farm to table restaurant must!
author: Kelley R.

description:
Its a bar whats not to like? 

I like this bar mostly for the half naked portraits on the wall. Its also a nice break from the standard dive bars. It feels like a true locals spot with the large wooden bar back.  They also have a small room in the back you can book for small parties. Definitely a spot worth checking out.   

If you like to gamble ask about the dice.
author: Joseph M.

description: Let me paint a picture...it's a beautiful rare sunny day in SF where everyone is happy and high off the vitamin D. We come here on an impromptu pub crawl for a friends bday & I hear the bartender yell "stop being so loud", and we were half of the patrons in there. Surly is one thing, but unwelcoming is another. Needless to say, I'm never ever going back again. Oh & to all the other bartenders out there, if there's a large party and a potential for a huge tip, don't blow it by yelling at us....literally.
author: Anastasia V.

description:
The Homestead is a confusing bar for me.

It is amazing 50% of the time. I think I can simplify this: half the staff are delightful, while the other half are completely unpleasant.

My last visit...

First round: Greeted by cheerful and funny bartender. She made me and my gf great drinks.

Second round: Bartender who hates her life made us drinks that had less than an ounce of alcohol in them because (obviously) she hates us too.

Getting purposefully shitty drinks at a bar makes you feel unwelcome. We chugged our mixers- I mean "cocktails"- and left.

This scenario has unfortunately replayed several times I've stopped in. It's like the bartenders are playing 'good cop, bad cop.'

They're dog friendly and the ambiance is lovely with gilded ceiling tiles, dark Victorian wallpaper and naked lady paintings in ornate frames. I want to like this place. Maybe if you're in the mood for beer and get the right bartender you won't have such a crappy experience.
author: K M.

description:
I've only been to Homestead three times (and only once since actually living in the mission), but I've told all of my friends (and friends of friends) about how great this place is.

It's definitely left a lasting impression, in a good way. Plus, they have all sorts of "fancy" Whiskey drinks for only $7!

I guess I would classify this as an upscale dive bar because the decor/atmosphere is nice, but the drink prices don't reflect it. It truly is a neighborhood bar!
author: Amber M.

description:
An Irish girl, a Scotsman and a Welshman walk into a SF bar on St Patrick's day...not only the start of a hilariously funny racist joke, this is actually a story of how St Patrick's day started for me this year.

Brought here by a true Irish renegade and a Scotsman with a penchant for an Irish goodbye, the place turns out to be a Welsh bar....SCORE! (I'm the 'Welshman' by the way, in case anyone was still trying to work that out).

Welcomed by quotes from Dylan Thomas on the walls and so many peanut husks you get the sense that you are walking on unbreakable bubble wrap, it set the scene for a bar that didn't take tidyness too seriously, and turned out that they were concentrating their efforts on making this a place with a great atmosphere and good Guinness...efforts that deliver on expectations I can reassure you!

A good time was had by all, many pints of Guinness were had by few and a shitload of peanut husks were later found in a number of orifices.

Thank you Homestead, for a night I will not soon remember, though I still try not to forget (think about that one a moment ;)
author: Elliot A.

description:
Jovial lighting, great ambiance, dogs under the tables, breasts on the walls, plenty of Fernet, and just enough peanut shells on the floor to remind you of the South(west).

Once left my credit card here and they still had it, months later. Great experience.
author: Megan G.

description:
I had always wanted to come in here after walking by after Mission Cliffs, and it did not disappoint. It gets a pretty good crowd on weeknights, and has a pretty fun atmosphere with lots of boobies on the wall. Drinks were good, though a little pricey, and again they charge for salty snacks, which sucks.

The "fun" part is throwing your peanut shells on the ground. Woo look we are so barbaric and don't have to pretend to be neat on dates! YIPPY!
author: Caitlin H.

description:
I live pretty much right next door so I thought this would be my neighborhood bar hang-out. I don't think get why it has such a high rating. Very hipster-ish and I guess that's why it has a high rating in the Mission.  

It has 4-5 tables inside, and bar stools. I think it would be hard for a big group to gather there, unless they rent the back room (which I heard is cheap - $20/hour). 

Cool thing - peanuts you get to throw on the floor and HH on Monday nights where it's $1 cans of cheap beer and cheap wells (maybe $3?)
They also bake pizzas outside on Thursday nights (maybe not every Thursday, but I've seen it a bunch) but I think they are almost $10 for a personal pizza.

I guess good to go if your not looking for a crazy night and just want to chill with a friend over a few beers.
author: Jessica S.

description:
A friend of mine best describe this place when he said "I could just sit and staring at that gold ceiling all night". So there you have it. This is a place that feels like it was built 100 years ago, rolled through 2 earthquakes, and hasn't changed a bit. Even the art is, well, just checkk it out.

I've been to many a soiree in the private backroom and the there is something about the padded walls there that is both curious and comforting.

There is a special every night and the owners are always donating something to a charity, so take the time to find out who they are supporting on that day.
author: Geoff H.

description: Not sure i enjoyed the naked women decor, but then again it is an old prohibition bar so what the hey. Our bartender was super nice and let me try different beers since i have a tendency to hate them all. I still do for the record. They only had one cider which was kind of a bummer but i didn't mind paying a dollar over half price for a half pint of it. Either way a cool bar. Not sure what its like when its full of people though.
author: Haylee C.

description:
I went to Homestead last night and was reminded of what a great bar it is.  I love this bar for many reasons.  It always has a good crowd, they carry all sorts of liquors, the bartenders know their stuff, they serve peanuts, and it is a good atmosphere.  

My friend and I had the best time last night.  We go out drinking often, and recently decided vodka was the new 'go-to' liquor for us to drink.  Being in the industry, we know vodka is considered an amateur's spirit.   This notion makes it embarrassing for us to order drinks.  However, the adorable female bartender last night made us several different vodka based drinks that we loved.  She had fun with it, did not make fun of us, and we really had a great time.  

My dad went to this bar when he was young and loved it.  He always brags to me about the cheap $.25 drinks he used to buy.  While the drinks are more expensive than they used to be, I know why this place is still as great as it is now, as it was 30 or more years ago.
author: Ashley W.

description:
My friend rented the back room for a party. This is a chill neighborhood bar with very good drinks. I don't know what people mean when they say there aren't mission-y people here. We got there a bit early so I was able to count the number of hipster dark rimmed glasses- 4 out of 15 people were wearing them! So I put on a fake pair to fit in. But I got caught by the bartender because I kept slipping them up over my hair like they were sunglasses. 

Anyway, delicious strong drinks? Yes. Awesome prices? DOUBLE YES. Moody lighting, topless paintings of women from the 70s, and an intensely 1920s decor vibe completed the picture. 

I'm not driving out of my way to hang out here, but if I'm in the area and thirsty, I'll head over.
author: Julia K.

description: May.22.2013. $9 ONE BEER: $7 Guinness Draft + $2 tip ... on a Tuesday night! Terrible service.  Expect to wait, notwithstanding the emptiness nor congestion of the bar  The female bartenders prefer to text or get phone numbers instead of serving drinks, and the males prefer serving regulars instead of strangers at the well.  I've been there three times now with consistently bad service, and have lived four blocks away since 2001.  Lesson learned and no more returns -- DOUCHEBAG CENTRAL STAY AWAY.
author: Benaminh L.

description:
I do so love this bar.  It's old and kind of sagging to one side, but it's always full of regulars and folks who work in the area, and the bar tenders are nice.  The old beautiful bar just begs to be gazed at, as do the breasts of the women in the velvet paintings....or are those paintings on canvas?  Anyway, full nudes are always great at bars. 

Last time I was here we made a place for ourselves at the bar, ordered our drink, and moseyed over to the piano where there was standing room only to take in the festive crowd.  It's not always so crowded at 6:30 on Friday, but there were 2 different groups celebrating goodbye-co-worker and birthday events of some kind.  

I proceeded to knock back the first drink I'd had in a month at Homestead; a glass of the house red, and NO drink of house red had ever tasted so good!
author: Melissa B.

description: Went on a monday. 3 dollar wells for the night. Had a great time. Great atmosphere. I'll definitely be going back.
author: Chris M.

description: Parked near Homestead while dining at Schmidt's.  On the way back we stopped in for a drink and had a nice surprise.  Good beer, friendly bar tender.  Vibe is blue collar hipster, no complaints.
author: Patrick S.

description:
You San Francisco kids don't give it a rest. 

This place was PACKED on a Monday. I can't remember going to a packed bar on a Monday beyond a college bar over the summer toting a bunch of already-wasted coeds waiting in line. This place was packed, no line and no drunk coeds stumbling around. 

There were however a lot of hipsters. Like, a lot. Now, my thin Miami blood isn't used to this PBR-drinking scene, so I was fascinated. Completely entranced. We navigated through this packed crowd, got some beers and stood around marveling at the naked lady pictures and board games going on near us. 

the crowd seemed friendly enough, but what really really impressed me was the GRILLED CHEESE CART outside - SERIOUSLY?! What could be better?! Some former-silicon-valley type sits outside and makes grilled cheese sandwiches - he'll even bring them into the bar for you. My friend Ben G. was raving about how amazing they were and had I not been on the verge of puking from eating too much at dinner I would have ordered one (or two) in a heart beat. 

Seriously. Grilled Cheeses. and beer. 
What an amazing winning combination. 
Love this local scene.
author: Caro D.

description: Homestead's so nice! Such an easy place and you can't go wrong with peanuts unless you're deathly allergic in which case you might die here. But for everyone else it's great!
author: Lisa K.

description:
I like how they accept credit cards. First and foremost.

Not quite in walking distance of any other bars worth visiting in my opinion, but this place left us happy with pretty fast service and good drinks. Not a huge place but good enough to gather a crowd.

Apparently people throw peanuts on the floor? I only saw this a little bit. Not as disgusting as you'd imagine so don't let that scare you away, germophobes.
author: Paul B.

description:
I frequently visit from Los Angeles and tonight, I was on a mission to find some gay hipsters (Is there even such a thing as a straight hipster?). Castro has few to none. The Mission district is the watering hole.

I loved the crowd. I am all about a variety of people. Straight, gay, hipster, fashion...
Rad fucking bar. I will be back Homestead!
author: JJ C.

description:
This is our local bar in the Mission. I was introduced to the Homestead by my housemate when I moved to SF.

The atmosphere is always laid-back, the bartenders are friendly and drinks are cheap. You can always expect to find a good crowd and a mix of characters. Great place to go for a beer and sit by the fireplace on a rainy day. You can usually easily find a seat by the bar.

They serve peanuts ($1 a basket) or you can bring your own food; some nights food kiosks are just outside the bar - pizza or tamales. Major games are shown.

I avoid busy nights, usually the weekends, but the rest of the week it's relatively quiet and laid back.

Go to the Homestead with a friend and enjoy a few drinks in a friendly atmosphere.
author: Marianna R.

description:
Always had a great time here. I actually love this place. 

I've read a couple of reviews about bad bartenders, and boy am I critical of that! But we have always had a good to great experience here with the bar. Even when I've ordered drinks they don't know, they make an effort to make it. I appreciate that. 

And of course the peanuts! $1 a basket and the shells go on the floor. Love that. 

They pour a pretty good 20 ounce Guinness as well. 

Many returns.
author: Jenny M.

description:
+4 for great service. Your hosts Deb and Libations McGee keep you well taken care of, witty-banter and drinks-wise. 

Homestead is a great place if you're looking for a local spot to have drinks with a pal, or come here with your large-headed dog (100+ lbs, not sure about their policy on wee dogs)...
author: Mark S. I.

description:
The first time we cam here, my bf's friend was in town for her birthday, we decided to explore the Mission a little bit, got some food, and was walking around deciding on a place to get some drinks when Yelp pointed us in the direction of Homestead. Because it's a place I had bookmarked and wanted to try, and we were half mile away, I made their asses walk over there with me. Yep!

It was a Thursday night, we got there around 8:30, and it was about half full. The bar has a wide selection of liquors, AND Boddington's beer on tap. double snaps! The Jukebox is full of David Bowie, Iggy Pop, Elvis Costello, Rolling Stones and other great rock. There's bowls of peanuts at the bar for you to munch on too!

I love the way the place looks- from the outside in. The side door was open when we got there, and although it was nippy out (lol, SF, when you not nippy?) the breeze felt nice. It made the peanut shells on the floor, under a bulldog sitting in a chair, swirl around on the floor. That's right- there are dogs allowed in this bar, on a leash, and every dog I've seen here (2 at most at one time, really) is well behaved, well groomed, and adorably friendly. (And no, the dogs are never bullied or given any booze.)

I see the word "hipster" in these previous reviews, and yeah, alright, I suppose. They're hip people, sure. But the people here are nice and friendly and funny as hell. Met some awesome people here! Reminds me of the places I used to frequent and my friends back home. 

The prices are consistent, reasonable, and LOW. Just the other night, 4 beers and 2 whiskey sours cost $25. I MEAN, COME ON. (That was pre tip, ladies & germs... tip your bartenders well. They are your friends.)

Let me divulge that I live in the Parkside. I trek over here often to enjoy the drinks and the atmosphere. It's become my special little watering hole, despite me living a decent amount of miles from it. It's worth going over to.
author: Savannah P.

description:
Picture an Irish/Welsh bar in San Francisco in your head, and you'll get Homestead precisely right. But what a fun place with an eclectic group of people, and $2 Tecates are always a lovely choice! You'll see every type of person, and the peanuts at the bar are wonderful for snacking after a few too many brews. 

I think my favorite moment of the evening came when myself and a couple others headed outside to smoke some cigars. This being San Francisco, the group next to us was smoking something legal in California, but not many other places. Ironically, the bartender walks outside, and tells us the CIGARS were bothering her even though we were further down the block, while the guys with the joints were clearly not an issue for her. Only in Cali I guess.

A great stop if you're doing a pub/dive bar crawl of SF. The city is packed with great places like this, but this was one of my favorites, and for sure worth checking out.
author: Collin S.

description:
OK, couldn't decide but I definitely think this is a 5-star place. Drinks are cheap ($5 for top-shelf liquors), service is fast, vibe is good. Plenty of places to sit - lots of stools by the bar and tables along the other side of the bar...and in the back.

I remember coming to this bar ages and ages ago when it was a different bar, and the decor is so much better. The decor is muted and understated but really nice.

There isn't much in the neighborhood which makes this place a destination for anybody who doesn't live in the area, but on a positive note, there was a ton of parking when we went on a Friday night!
author: Wendy L.

description: This is my new favorite bar in SF. I don't live there anymore, but heard about this place and on my next trip north to the city, I made sure to go. With my dog in tow, of course. Everyone was lovely, the bouncer picked my lovely pooch up and gave her a kiss. It was midweek, so the bar wasn't too crowded, and I let Olive (my dog) off her leash and she spent the next several hours roaming through the bar and making friends. The bartenders are sweet as candy, the prices are cheap, and the vibe is super neighborhoody. Plenty of hipsters, sure, but older locals, chill friends, little bit of everyone. I'm sure some people will find the dog-friendliness a drag, so to those people I suggest going to a different spot. Sure, you might spill some of your drink due to an errant wagging tail, but at these prices, you can afford to. Go.
author: Jayson M.

description: I am mystified by all the glowing reviews for this bar. My $5 cider definitely hit the spot on a hot day in the city but I didn't enjoy the isolated location, lack of AC, and the proliferation of buzzing flies. Eep.
author: Meghan B.

description:
This is my watering hole.  I just opened my business in the Mission and the first thing I wanted to do when I opened the doors was to find the neighborhood bar where I can go after I work or celebrate a sale.  I found such a place in Homestead.  My business partner and I have gone there several times to celebrate a good sale and I have always been happy when I leave. 

I like the peanut shells on the floor and that the neighborhood dogs are sometimes sniffing around. I like the paintings on the wall, and the great display of good scotch.  You can also order from some neighborhood food joints who deliver to the Homestead.
author: Marty W.

description:
I can see myself really liking this bar eventually, but the night I went (on a Saturday) it was packed to the point where I could hardly breathe. Why in the world did they let SO many people inside? Hm.

Peanuts on the tables, a nice touch. Good variety of drinks, nice atmosphere-- I did not feel like I was in the Mission (good for me, no offense).

I liked that they had an outside section on the sidewalk for those that need a breath of fresh air, or a smoke break. It was easiest for me to go out the front door and come in the side door in order to skip the crowded mess on my way to the bathroom and vice versa. There's only one bathroom stall for women, behind a wooden door, kind of in the center of the bar, ehhhh. The door is tiny too, like it was made by a leprechaun.

Still, a fun time in the Mission, none-the-less. I'll be back to this bar.
author: Ashley D.

description: Peanuts! Dollar beers! Dogs scoping out peanut shells on the floor! Its a fun crowd here and while visiting from LA I enjoyed the chill vibe and bartenders. The decor in here is warm and inviting, you can sit and drink away your sorrows all night long.
author: Rachel A.

description:
I'm a little biased because my friend is kind of like the "it" guy at the Homstead...and when I come here I roll with him and I'm part of the really cool, wish you were part of it too, group.  As a result, we always get treated well here...but I think I'd be treated well here anyway, it's just that kind of cool place.

I love that they play soul music often...and I'm always really tempted to push the tables apart and just start dancing.  It's so chill and laid back and just a really good place to hang out with your friends that you haven't seen in a very long time because you used to live in another part of the country and now you're finally back with the cool kids in SF.
author: Quynh-An P.

description:
Nothing special about this bar.  Interior is cool.  There's a juke box, but can't hear a damn thing.  To top if off, there's a rude ass bartender that works on Thursday nights that left a bad taste in my mouth.  Not only does she get wasted while working, but gets annoyed when you order multiple drinks.  Oh and don't bother leaving any type of change with a bill as tip (ex. $1.50), she'll throw the quarters right back at you.  Seriously?!

If the bartender is a heavy set blond with a funny looking face, avoid her at all costs.  Better yet, go to another bar where the bartenders are cool and don't act like divas.
author: Alex L.

description:
Couldn't ask for a better winter local! 

Dollar peanuts, fireplace, great brown liquors on offer and a top notch crowd.

SOLD
author: David B.

description:
Let me first say that I hate...HATE...that this review requires two stars, because I really, really like this bar. I live in the hood and have been a handful of times in the last year or so, and it's always been cool. Love the dogs, the peanuts, the wallpaper, the jukebox. All of it. 

This review is less a review of the bar, and more a review of the bartender. Here goes: Dear girl bartender with the long dark hair and tattoos: You. Are. Awful. My boyfriend and I came in on Friday night, right around 7:30. You were not busy. We sat down at the bar, I smiled a hello at you. You did not smile back. Fine. You waited on someone else who sat down around the same time we did. No worries there, we'll be next, right? Nope. It's time to wait on the guy who JUST walked up to the bar. You're smiling at him and being super friendly. Encouraging! So excited to order our drinks! Oh, but wait....now you're helping the girl who literally just walked up right next to me. You're being really nice to her, as well. Maybe...now...we can...no? You're going to wait on another couple who are basically standing behind us? Oh, but you're being a super bitch to them, but hey, at least they're getting a drink (you don't like couples, honey, do you?)

Ugh. At this point I ASKED her if we could order drinks and she responded with "yep" without making eye contact. The only reason she's getting two stars instead of one is that she made me a proper whiskey drink and poured a proper beer for my boyfriend.  I can't understand why she was being so nasty to us, as I don't typically inspire nastiness in bartenders (I've had loads of bartender friends over the years, and I know how to be a good customer), but she's ensured that I'll never, ever come back in for a drink. Thanks, terrible bartender. Your boss must be so proud.
author: heather c.

description:
I was fortunate enough to have been introduced to this place, the Homestead, by a new acquaintance of mine, and we went on a night that was busy, but not too busy.

Homestead's exterior seems like many other bars in San Francisco. The Victorian facade remind me of the 1800's when people roved the streets with horse and carriage. The corner entrance makes me imagine a pair of flapping bar doors where cowboys and gamblers swing aside on their way to feed their additions.

Once I walked in I saw a room of colorful, very hip bar patrons. They plaid shirts and driving caps filled the room. A few out-of-place individuals hugged the walls like flies.

In the back is a room for renting if you so wish. I asked about it for my birthday, and was told by friends it's as cheap as $20 for the evening. Unfortunately they have just raised the rate to $50 a night. understandable. The room fits about 20 people and has chairs and tables. I will find a reason to use it eventually.

I felt completely at home there (no pun intended). The others attending that evening were gracious and inviting. I likely would have made some good, three hour friends if I had had more to drink. I may yet, since I'll be going there more often.

Good for out of town folks to show them the SF scene.
author: Seth F.

description: This is a charming little place, although it always seems to take awhile to get served drinks.  It's also off the beaten path so it may not be worth going out of your way.  It almost earns an extra star for being dog friendly.  Almost!
author: Vanessa L.

description:
Came here with friends before an art show nearby and it was pretty packed for a Thursday after work. There weren't any free tables so we ended up pulling some chairs up to a piano. Weird thing is that there's plenty of room for more tables to be scattered about. Sort of loud, so be prepared to use your outdoor voice. Also good to know - there was a BBQ dude outside. Crazy good pulled pork sliders.

Dogs are allowed at this bar so don't be alarmed if you're sitting down and make a new four legged friend!
author: Karena Q.

description:
I love this bar, I love the Shellac Shack on Monday nights.
The bar is cute and quaint and antiquey and CLEAN and filled with a mix of Missiony type people and seriously?  The bathrooms are CLEAN with no graffiti or pee on the floor or what have you. . . at least for happy hour midweek.  Oh and free peanuts!!!
The bartenders could maybe use some training in classic cocktails, but that's what I get for trying to order a freaking "Bramble" here.  My bad, but it wouldn't hurt, know what I'm sayin?
No matter, I'm still moving in.
author: Jennifer D.

description: This is definitely one of the chillest bars I've ever been to. The crowd is very SF. Not very many sleezy guys but mostly hipster/artsy folk. The atmosphere is laid back and the staff seem really nice. The tables, decoration, and piano give it a very interesting look and feel. I'd definitely recommend hitting this place up if you're bar hopping in the mission.
author: Zohreh A.

description:
Oh Homestead, how do I love thee? Let me count the ways: 

Oil porn: check
Peanuts: check
Cheap pitchers of Tecate: check
Oil porn: check again
Surly bartender who will repeatedly steal your glass of whiskey/beer before you're finished with it: check
Presence of 6-time champions of the UCSF Recreational Sports  Intermediate men's basketball league, Los Strawberitos: check

I love this place so much, I plan on naming my first child Homestead (if it's a girl, Homesteadia). Come by on Tuesday night if you want to get your vintage Strawberitos memorabilia signed.
author: Ben N.

description:
The Homestead's gotta be one of my favorite bars in San Francisco.  Not because it's got everything that other bars don't, but because it hasn't got much of what the other bars got.

Less is more here.  The beauty(or appearance of such) is in her simplicity. 

The staff is super friendly and generous with the peanuts and the jukebox.  San Francisco doesn't have any scooter bars anymore, but if there was one; the Homestead would be it.  Well maybe it's a part time scooter bar. How's that?

I can't say enough about the place.  It's like home.  For awhile it was like my Cheers.  If I rode in there on any given day, whether it would be Monday after work or Saturday night, I was bound to run into someone I knew.  Homestead, I miss ya girl.  I'll come back one day!
author: Marcos R.

description:
One of my favorite bars in the Mission, for when I'm looking for something a step above divey, but still casual.

This place has a warm (literally - there's a fireplace) cozy feeling that makes it a great place to go have a drink with friends. The bartenders are friendly, the drinks are affordable (good draught beer selection), the artwork on the wall is awesome, and the free peanuts are a nice extra touch.

Very much a locals bar (with few hipsters).
author: Mark A.

description: Vodka gimlet, limey and potent in  an elegant , victorian  goblet. The bar has high tin ceilings and red flocked bordello wallpaper. Naked lady portraits give a men's club vibe. im told you can bring food in, but none is served, Which means i can bring meebow, san franCisco's only registered dogbassador. She likes the homestead cuz patrons drop peanuts on the floor. She shnuffled the droppings all night long. The bar is a nice wrap around style, plenty of rooms, and there are small and large communal tables. The peeps are varied, we chatted with bearded thirty-somethings and middle aged artists. Friendly crowd, you could go by yourself and be comfortable. I could probably drop the meeb off and she'd make more friends than me! Location is also great, you can find free street parking nearby.
author: Kelly K.

description:
I like my beer with boobies.

And there are plenty of retro tits on the walls of this place. Classy nudes, though. 

Aside from that, The Homestead, is comfy, not too dark, full of peanuts and hot mens... which is always fun for a single gal. 

mmmmm... peanuts and hot mens....

bartenders aren't too friendly- which you know... is average, but sucks. 
Chill spot, only drag... out in the cuts so you can't really bar hop.
author: Nnekay F.

description: I really like this bar. Friendly staff, tasty cocktails, cosy atmosphere. It loses one star because of the dearth of toilets but that's an SF thing. I hate wasting my night in line.
author: Kate A.

description:
Great place.  Maybe my new favorite bar in San Francisco.  It's a good thing that I live miles away in the Richmond or I'd probably be sloshed here every night.  

The decor of this place is what really makes it shine.  It has that old Victorian feel with the beautiful original ceiling paneling, the Victorian wallpaper, and a guy in the back spinning jazz records.  

The bar area is small and intimate and there is some table seating scattered about, but the place is relatively small so I'm sure on certain nights it can get real packed.

The beer prices are reasonable, and on Monday nights they have some sort of dollar beer night going on which brought in a fair share of hipsters all of which were jovial and non-pretentious.  

Seriously, this place is great and I am already finding excuses to head over to the Mission just to have a reason to stop by this lovely bar.
author: T.C. J.

description:
It's kind of like if, halfway through her self-imposed exile from the world, Lady Havisham (of Great Expectations), decided to turn her time-frozen room into a Victorian brothel. It's dark, the walls appear to have velvety Victorian wallpaper on them, and if you pay close enough attention, there are some paintings of topless ladies here and there.

Get there early and get a drink, and you'll have a great little place to catch up with friends. It does get louder and more crowded late.

Prices of drinks are reasonable, too.
author: Leelah P.

description:
Homestead is one of those places that makes San Francisco great and because of that, it's become one of my favorite local neighborhood watering holes. With a great selection of beers, whiskeys and nice bartenders, this place is definitely properly named. 

Nude paintings featuring lovely ladies with lovely boobies (who doesn't like boobies?) on the walls and gorgeous victorian wallpaper completes the awesome factor and makes this a 5-star joint. 

Cheers.
author: Jono K.

description:
Us: Two 30-somethings enjoying a few after dinner drinks at this friendly and reasonably priced establishment. 

Them: One hundred 23-year olds celebrating their class of 2004 high school reunion.

It made for an amusing scene, especially as we all got chatting waiting in line for the bathroom, more drinks, etc. They were completely confident they'd be repeating this scene for the ten year, fifteen year and so on. When I shared my graduation year (not '04), they asked if we were still celebrating. I smiled and offered up my two cents that you are about to enter this fantastic period of self-discovery, new experiences, new friends, etc., and come the ten year mark, you won't know most of these people anymore. And you won't really care.

They didn't believe me, but that could have been the drinks talking. I might be back 12/23/14 to find out who was right.
author: Jason B.

description:
Peanuts, pints and... more pints. 

From the $2 Olympias to the $3 Rum and Cokes (seriously, in SF at 10 p.m.?), you're bound to leave here with a light head and a heavy wallet. Peanut shells crunch under your feet as you smoosh and bump your way to the bar, but that's part of Homestead's charm. Other charmers including the vintage nudies on the wall (I like to have dudes guess the bra sizes of said vintage nudie ladies), the back room (which you can rent for $20!!), and the massive windows for that good ol' fashion doggie watchin. 

Sure, it gets a little crowded. But for a bar that accepts cards with no minimum, baskets of fresh peanuts, low prices, and is a short walk from my doorstop, I'm so down to wiggle my way through the crowds.
author: Leslie W.

description:
Homestead is a great place  to grab a drink with friends. Thisplace has a old country san franciscan victorian atmosphere. It's inviting and comfortable,

Besdies a decent selection of beers they have gret selction o rum and of course the Whiskys specially american bourbon and rye whiskeys. The bar tenders are friendly an will accomodate your request.

It's also a great place for first date!
author: Subhash J.

description: Used to be a big fan, but the bartenders were consistently rude too many times in a row. There are plenty of places I'd rather spend my money.
author: Will A.

description: I like this bar for many reasons (i.e. the nice selection of whiskey, the fireplace, the decent jukebox, and the pics of nudie ladies on the wall), but mostly, it's the only place where I can munch peanuts and dump their shells right on the floor. In other words, I can be my slob of a self and it's totally acceptable. Finally.
author: Christina S.

description: Any bar that allows dogs gets 2 paws up from Moo and Mee.  They had a great time hanging out.  They did stay away from the big giant dog roaming about because he was a little intimidating.  Us humans were happy with the drinks.
author: Cianne M.

description: I normally like this place. However, on one recent visit the two lady bartenders were condescending and rude. All five people in my group (3 guys, 2 females) noticed that we were being mocked whenever one of us went to order a drink. At last call, all the bar tenders yelled "LAST CALL" and stared directly at us. I thought they wanted our money. Guess they don't want it anymore.
author: Kimling L.

description:
I really really wanted to like this place. I'm a sucker for dive bars and old timey ones at that -- dark wood, stamped tin ceilings, etc etc. But the open dogs policy has gotten out of control.  When we first arrived, one cute lassie type running around. Then a pit bull and a giant poodle and more -- and the dogs kept snarling and leaping at each other. Their owners obliviously sat there as the dogs nipped in the air at the chair my friend was sitting in, eventually driving her to leave. Another friend's eyes turned bright red from the allergies to dogs, though she tried to stick it out for my sake.

And yet these are the same kind of hipsters who would whine about babies in the restaurants.  Hypocrites!  Dogs in bars are cool, if they are under control.
author: Vanessa H.

description: This is a great bar.  There's a pot-bellied wood-burning stove, friendly bartenders and a good locals crowd.  A beautiful hammered tin ceiling, too!  The decor is a little different from the prevailing Edwardian/Steampunk and lives up to the name of the place.  Could use a revamped beer selection, but they do have a few nice ones.  Huge and impressive Whiskey selection, but Whiskey ain't my thing:)
author: Lauren J.

description: Dope bar in the Mission keep an eye out for the tamale lady! Yes they let her in to sell tamales. Another reason this spot was dope they let you bring food in hahah they let us bring food from Taqueria Cancún  a few blocks down. Place can get pretty crackin!
author: Steph S.

description:
This place, was awesome. Good crowd, awesome ambiance, killer music, and great drink selection.

I came here on a Monday night and the place was pretty packed. My girlfriends and I had done some bar hopping beforehand and were skeptical at first about coming out to 19th and Folsom, but upon entering Homestead were immediately taken by the bar. 

Drinks were reasonably priced and the crowd was very cool. In fact my two single friends were going down the bar counting how many attractive males they saw.

Amusedly, I stood by drinking my Anchor Steam and thinking how much places like this make me miss living in San Francisco.
author: Rebecca M.

description: Homestead is a fun bar.  My favorite part; they have a comfy private room that you can reserve ahead of time for $20 and then have guaranteed seating for you and a roomful of your closest drinking buddies.  We did this just last night, and had an awesomely chill night.
author: Tasha D.

description:
I'm obliged to use the word obliged, to tip a mercury-rimmed derby cap and feign being a steampunk who is an outsourced huckster for Homestead, creating tumbleweeds on Folsom and establishing notions that this was once an apothecary and spirits from said establishment still are apt to be stirred. 

Why you ask? Because Homestead, on a whippet's whim, agreed with me that if I went from patron to patron to coordinate a last call all-together-cry of the Dylan Thomas quote above the bar with everyone, that it can & should happen. 

I could say the $2 Tecates had a lot to do with it. I could say that my tendency to get Irish & Welsh-y slurry after six hours of pinting was increased. Maybe it was the decorum. Or the spirits. More than likely it was my infatuation with the wall paper and ceiling and the bartenders being as welcoming as everything here. Maybe it was that I remember them opening when I lived down the street and scrubbing the front window. Who knows... what I do know is that the people that flock here are down for such a tumbling social mistake to approach folks with such an inquiry. And then, they're most definitely down to do the last call recital of the quote. Those are welcoming owners. Those are open patrons. That's a damn affable bar. And this instance of compulsive convening & conviviality trumps any conniving overprice jukes & drinks or snide cocktail houses that's competing for the spotlight in this city. 

The stand up piano in the corner may or may not have been playing by itself after the entire bar of... say roughly 40 folks... all together sung the saying.
author: Jon A.

description:
Feels like a neighborhood bar, with plenty of seating (relative to its size), but isn't a total dump like most small bars.  I didn't feel like I might get AIDS from touching the walls, for example.  There's also a fireplace and even nudity on the walls!  A few of my favorite things.

I'll definitely come back.
author: Ankur P.

description: The Homestead is hands down my favorite bar in town. It's off the beaten path with a friendly atmosphere, cool decor, reasonably priced drinks, and amazing staff. What more could you want?
author: Kitty F.

description:
This is a solid bar. Decked out with the classy saloon decor. Good beer selection, friendly bartenders and $1 peanuts that you get to throw on the ground while you're enjoying your beer. They're dog friendly too! 

Joined my girlfriend and her co-workers for a going away party here last night. We had a small but private room in the back reserved for the occasion. Shared endless baskets of peanuts, had a couple pints of beer, and a few of their Thursday night Pizza Specials, including the thin crust pepperoni and margarita pizza. They were tasty but the crust was too thin for my taste.  

Would definitely come back! Loving the Guinness!
author: crystal e.

description: Though I don't go very often, this is probably my favorite bar in town.  This pub used to be a Welsh pub called Dylans and it has a rather international crowd Thursdays and Fridays before 8. I like this place because of the people, the events, and yes, the peanuts.
