You get to throw down the shells on the ground so it feels a little Barbary by the Bay. Like you ought to be spouting off some Hemingway and writing your novel in the corner.  But wait, there's also the fireplace and the fact that they let people bring dogs in, which really makes it feel like a pub. All that ambiance, and I forgot to mention that they serve booze.  Anchor on tap, Chimay,and if you're up for it a full bar.  My favorite boozer.
author: J S.

description: I've been wanting to check this joint out for a while now and finally made my way the other night.  I was about 7 drinks in already but could still tell the vibe, decor and clientele were very cool, including the two dogs hanging out with the crowd.  But that is where the fun ended. Why, you ask?  Because of the complete grump bitch-ass of a bartender.  Girl, you work in a cool, fun bar with potentially great drinks, put half a freakin smile on your face when your customers order a drink?  No?  Then go F yourself and thanks for ruining the entire experience for me and my friends.  Seriously, she should be fired.
author: e w.

description: Ok bar, friendly service, peanuts on the floor, naked ladies on the walls.
author: Oleg H.

description: This bar is in a great location to hang out at while waiting to go to Flour & Water.  And to go back to after dinner.  I like this bar because it has a cool vibe and super cheap drinks!
author: Lindsay L.

description:
As a former bartender/cocktail server I am always patient at waiting for drinks. But on Tue 6/25 I go in to wait 10 minutes for both bartenders to finish their conversations before making anyone a drink. The shorter (more tatooed) girl did not even look up for a full 10 minutes while a "local" spoke to her. I waved to him after 5 minutes (code for stop talking dude, I would like some service). He looked at me and ignored me. The taller of the two girls finally saw me, finished patting a small dog at the bar, didn't wash her hands then made us both a drink. By the time the shorter girl looked around we had been served but 6 people had walked in and were waiting for someone to serve them. She didn't flinch, just stayed super-slow.
I can't believe I even tipped them. I tried to call the place today to explain this before yelping but there's no answer and no answering machine.
I guess you gotta be a local and waste your life in this bar to be served. I've lived in SF 20 years and have rarely gotten service this lousy.
Won't go back here and I encourage others to do the same.
author: M H.

description: I love how no one here is trying to front. It i just a downright cool bar with peanut shells on the ground. I loved the old wooden bar. The ice cold Anchor Steam was oh-so-delicious :-) If you are from the Midwest it is very reminiscent of The Nomad in Mpls or Milwaukee.
author: Melanie B.

description:
I love this bar but more importantly my dog loves this bar. 

The staff and customers are 100% dog friendly. They even keep a water bowl under the jukebox and dog biscuits at the bar. 

The beer is reasonably priced and it never takes long to get a drink.
author: Amy L.

description: This is a good neighborhood bar.  Barteneder got to us in a timely fashion when the place was fairly busy.   Peanuts at the bar and a fun atmosphere.  I will be back again, just wish they had one or 2 more tv's for sports games.
author: Nicole W.

description: Yup, all in. I've always wanted to go here and as chance had it last night was the night.  Cool place, way mellow.  Cute guy sitting at the bar named Ryan gave me the whiskey run down based on that fact that I smelled 'amazing'.  Yup, it was that kind of night.  Tons of parking, not to fret.  I'd go back in a heart beat.
author: Nicole F.

description: This place has $1 PBRs on Mondays. Repeat This place has $1 PBRs on Mondays. The drink prices are amazing here. The people are rad, the ambiance is great, it is a great atmosphere. Win Win Win.
author: Nicholas A.

description: My ID just expired and the bouncer wouldn't let me in with an alternate ID showing my age. I'm over 30 and it's clear so if you don't drive like me make sure to get your license renewed before coming here. I'll never bring my friends here again.
author: Gary A.

description: Horrible Bartenders. She ruined the entire night with her condescending,rude,mocking behavior.
author: Larry W.

description:
Victorian saloon meets hipster dive bar.  Fuzzy wallpaper lines the walls and peanuts cover the floor.  Drinks are cheap and there's no credit card minimum. 

If you're looking for an unpretentious after-work drink, this is a great spot.
author: Zuzzi E.

description:
This place definitely has an old school feel considering it's existence began over 100 years ago. I can imagine gold miners and cowboys coming in here for a whiskey and maybe a friendly poker game after a hard day. 

We came here for my friend's birthday this past weekend and there's a private room in the back that's usually $20 an hour and we actually got the room for free from the previous occupants that left early so it actually turned out pretty good considering we had a gang of people. Bar tenders were attentive and efficient and one of them was lovely and me and my friends couldn't stop ogling her. You know who you are cute bartender. Brunette with bangs and leather pants. We'll see you again and I'm sure we'll flirt with you some more.

Bar is definitely off the beaten path but definitely still always busy on the weekend. Jukebox is a little lacking but they do sell shell peanuts. Dope.
author: David C.

description:
"Don't go gently into that good night. Rage, rage against the dying of the light."

When visiting a drinking establishment what apt words of Dylan Thomas to be emblazoned above the bar, hmm? Especially one that's been going strong since 1905.

Situated in an area I only walk through en route to Mission Cliffs, the warm glow and bowed heads coaxed me in. With its turn-of-the-century dark mouldings, tin ceilings, wood burning stove and peanut shells chucked onto the floor, the atmosphere feels old-timey and comfortable. What really captivated was the shelves of suberb whiskey and slow sweet smiles of the barkeep.

Though it's a short dash from the 16th St BART, the blocks deter the hipster crowds making it a relaxed spot for a swirl or pint. Another century to the Homestead!
author: Ligaya T.

description:
I came here last week... or this week? Anyway, I came here on a Tuesday. I loved the decor and the history behind the bar. I've only recently been living in San Francisco but I would highly recommend to take out-of-town friends here for a piece of non-touristy SF history. The place has been around for over 100 years! 

I only had a beer there, Lagunitas.. must go back and try something else. I'm not sure if they have any signature drinks but that would be neat. Oh and they have peanuts for $1! And you can throw the shells all over the ground - yay for being messy!
author: Tatyana K.

description:
4.5 Stars 

Once again, my friend, Dalane, has not missed with this awesome bar recommendation. I would've never discovered this gem on my own! 

This saloon has been around since 1905, and has so much character and charm, without trying too hard. Interior has a cozy feel, and is simple with awesome wall paper. As we made our way to the end of the bar, we were greeted by a huge, yet friendly pooch (whom everyone pets). I believe he belongs to one of the owners, and is a regular at the Homestead. Anyway, there's a great beer selection, and even serve half bottles of the 'champagne of beers.' The bartenders were super friendly and attentive and checked up on us frequently. Did I mention the peanuts yet? Dalane says they're free but saw a sign by the bar that it was $1 a basket. Regardless, that's just an added charm to this place, and don't be surprised to see tons of peanut shells on the floor. 
The crowd is diverse with old and young hipsters, and talent wasn't bad at all! Everyone appeared to be friendly and not pretentious. 
I really loved the chill vibe of this place, and will definitely be back.
author: Gill C.

description:
Good bar, but like many others have said it gets really packed on the weekends.It gets loud and stuffy also. I wouldn't expect warm and friendly service but these guys and gals get the job done (minus a smile).

I would stick to early evening hours to avoid too much of a crowd.
author: Nick H.

description:
I was cool until a bunch of hippie freaks took over half the bar and started doing their hipppie freak shit all up in my space...I like it classy (clearly) and this sort of ruined the whole thing for me.

On the upside, this bar is awesome when there aren't hippie freaks doing impromptu a cappella tribal music/dance performances in the back half of the bar, where the lady's restroom happens to be. I am the Princess and the Pee and need to make frequent trips, especially when (lots of) vodka sodas are involved. Minus one star for not asking those fools to quit it.

The bar is warm and cozy, long and narrow, and will tolerate just about every kind of drunk yuppy or hipster or tech geek that SF has to offer. The bar itself is old and beautiful and they will give you free peanuts in a wooden bowl that your friends can repeatedly turn over, dumping all the peanuts on the table. Because they are raging drunks. 

Go to this bar. Drink a lot. Spill some peanuts. Invite me along. Avoid hippies at all costs. They smell and they just might get tribal on your ass.
author: Autumn K.

description:
Great place for a birthday party.  You can rent the back room for ONLY $25 and it all goes to charity!  What's more, there is no minimum bar tab.

Other than one surly lady who cleared the tables, the employees are super nice and prices are reasonable.  

Only 2 bad things about the back room - there is no ventilation, so it gets hot.  Also, the music from the jukebox doesn't reach back there, so aside from your boisterous friends, it's quiet - no tunes.
author: Christine M.

description: Went to Homestead a few weeks ago with a buddy of mine and I really liked it!  It's dog friendly and there's a nice little fireplace in the corner that makes it a nice warm spot to have some drinks with friends.  The volume is just quiet enough to have a conversation.  The peanuts were messy buy yummy.  All in all, this is a casual, cozy little bar that's perfect for conversation.  oooh, and they make great manhattans!
author: Preethi C.

description:
RACIST! RACIST! RACIST!!!!

 If you are going there with a crowd of minorities, don't bother to patronize them! RUN away from Homestead!  

It's amazing to see how this restaurant is still going strong when they discriminate against minorities. Thanks to yelp, it's truly my pleasure to reveal their character before they hurt anyone else. I wish I could give them 0 points but yelp won't let me. Bummer!

The bar was packed on a sat night and finally the back room became available so our party of 8 (mixed w/Black, Hispanic, and Asian) sat down. About 15 min later, they kicked us out and told us that they had to shut down the back room for tonight and no one else was supposed to be there anymore. We complied since we didn't know that no one was supposed to be in the back room when the door was wide open and inviting. Shortly after, they allowed a group of white people in there instead. When we asked the bar manager Christine what that was all about, she got upset, gave us an attitude bullshit answer that didn't make sense, didn't allow us to see the VIP book, and to top it all off -Christine made a scene and screamed at us to leave the bar for no apparent reason and yelled that we were all banned from that place.  All we did was ask why she kicked us out of the room and she couldn't answer us.

  What she didn't know was that the guard had already told us that no one else was on the VIP book since it was too late to RSVP by that time and that no one was supposed to be in the back room anymore for the rest of the night.  Hah! Christine, you are an evil person and just got caught in your lies! All I can say is karma will be a bitch!

Beware of this place because they are RACIST!
author: Jenn S.

description:
A bar that allows me to eat peanuts throwing the shells on the ground while I drink my beer.  The same bar allows dogs and has pictures of half-naked girls on the wall?  Oh hell yeah I'm so sold.  

I'm a simple kind of girls and these things make me happy.
author: Ke-Bear Z.

description:
The signage outside tells us that the Homestead has been here since 1905. The nightlife crowd is fickle in this town and if you last 103 years you're doing something right. Offering reasonably priced drinks, keeping historic features like tin stamped ceiling tiles and wainscoting intact without turning the place into a kitschy theme bar, and generally creating an inviting, unpretentious atmosphere are generally the right things to do.

Bear in mind that in 1905 I'm pretty sure this part of town was still a swamp, so people would routinely endure knee-deep mud and mosquitos and brigands to come drink here. These days there are still brigands but no mud or mosquitos and parking isn't even that hard. Don't forget how easy you've got it.
author: matthew r.

description:
When I moved to the neighborhood and passed this place I knew it would be one of my regular imbibing spots. On Mondays well drinks are super cheap and they make pretty decent margaritas. I love that it has a lot of history and the patrons aren't overly obnoxious. The decor is perfect.

The problems is that the bartenders often have really shitty attitudes. I've had much friendlier folks serve me in much busier bars. So we've stopped going there very often because I can't stand feeling like I've put surly bartender out because I had the audacity to politely order a DRINK at a BAR.
author: Sara M.

description:
Peanuts, beer and fuzzy wallpaper.  Well then!

Here's what you'll find at Homestead: 
- Beer you like, whether it's $2 Tecate or $6 Chimay you're craving.  Liquor instead?  No problem.
- Bartenders that take credit cards and serve snacks.  Above and beyond the call for hospitality in the Mission.
- Dogs with friendly owners.  
- A padded room.  Highly recommended for birthday engagements... as other have mentioned, the $25 rental fee is donated to charity.
- A Mission-esque crowd.  The good kind.
author: Gretchen S.

description: If you could turn me into a physical space (by a process that might include some kind of time warp to before Howard became South Van Ness and careening through the rough & tumble South of the Slot and consorting with the wild raven-haired wantons who no doubt intoxicated a visiting Rudyard Kipling and on the way back stopping in on the Decemberists recording "We Both Go Down Together" in some old church, and then pouring yourself a stiff Bulleit and patching together long lost friends into something tangible again, well then my friend) it would be this bar. (but I would throw some antiquing varnish on those tin ceilings, yo.)
author: Megan W.

description:
San Francisco needs more bars like the Homestead.

You hear that, SF? Stop trying to be so freakin' COOL, and just be what you are!

An old town, full of old buildings, that were all built either in the second half of the 19th Century, or just after the 1906 earthquake. Celebrate your architecture for what it is. Victorian/Edwardian. Dark, and creaky, and wooden, and dusty.

The bar here is awesome. So's the ceiling. And the potbelly stove. And the wooden floor all covered with peanut shells... I feel like a gold-diggin' homesteader every time I walk in.

The Homestead makes me FEEL LIKE A 49'ER (and I never thought I'd say that).

And while you're at it, you're a small town, too. You have 700,000 people. New York has 8,000,000. You are not the "Manhattan of the West." People in NYC can be "hip," pompous, assholes. But you, my fellow San Franciscans -- you have to be nice to each other. You're going to keep RUNNING IN to each other.

So do like they do at the Homestead, and just be cool.

Now, drink your beer and eat your peanuts...
author: Lisa T.

description:
Stumbled upon this place on my way home from a show at A.Muse Gallery to Mission St to catch the 49, and was lured in by the fantastic old-timey folk music and warm lighting emanating from within.

Beautiful wallpaper, ceiling, light fixtures, and bar.  It looked as though it hasn't changed since it opened in 1904, aside from the clientele, which seemed to be mix of Mission hipsters and neighborhood folk.

Super chill vibe, friendly and quick bartender, large and cheap drinks.

Can't wait to go back next time I'm in the neighborhood.
author: Brendon C.

description:
There are a few things running through my mind right now that I just have to get out of my system. 

How in the world was Homestead established in 1901 or whatever early 20th century date is plastered on their window when I clearly remember this place being Dylans not that long ago? Am I 35 in dog years?*

Is it just me or is this whole semi-tacky half naked woman painting on the wall thing becoming just way too cliche? I can think of at least four other places in this city, off the top of my head, with poorly painted boobies on the wall. It. Is. Not. Original. It is almost, and I say almost with hesitation, as tacky as the gold colored tin roof trying hard to be a Georgian style gilded ceiling. 

Minus one for the things about this place I do not understand. Plus four stars for a really unpretentious neighborhood spot. Friendly, laid back bartenders and patrons, some well poured beverages and a decor that is very comfortable as long as you don't look straight up or at some of the "art" adorning the walls.

*UPDATE 7/1 - I hate admitting when I am wrong and hanging my head in shame as I pull my foot out of my mouth but here it goes....I have been informed that this particular location was indeed opened at "The Old Homestead" in 1902 as a saloon. It has changed names and is now back to its original one. On the upside I no longer have to lose sleep at night that I am 35 in dog years instead of human years. That would have made me much older than I really am.
author: Drue C.

description: New favorite place. Very unassuming. Peanut shells on the floor. Dogs running around. Saloon Vibe. And their gimlet with vodka goes down like a limeade! I will definitely be back soon!
author: Laura L.

description:
I walked into this joint and immediately felt at home. The wallpaper reminded me of an old Parisian bordello. The bar was reminiscent of a gold rush saloon. The customers ran the gamut from greasers, to crusty old Irishmen, to yuppies. There was a fire crackling in the fireplace in the corner. Peanut shells cracked under my feet.The barmaids were slightly surly, which I appreciate.

Oh crap, if this combination of flavors is where I feel most at home, I had a most questionable upbringing.

But really, this place rules. Big time. And it's in one of the best neighborhoods in town. Mine.
author: Rachel F.

description:
What's going to be my 400th review?  Hmm . . . . anything I've missed from the past few weeks?  Oh yeah, Homestead.  

Wonderful little neighborhood bar.  When I used to live near Bryant and 22nd, this was called "Dylan's Pub" and I bet you can't guess which Irish poet this was named after.  Apparently Dylan's went not so gently into that good night.  It was a decent little spot, but didn't offer the down-home neighborhood flavor that Homestead does.  It's the kind of bar that makes you want to be unemployed in the Mission and have an excuse to hang out 'till all hours.  Actually, I kind of wish they were here when this was my 'hood - all we had was a more divey, less friendly place on Shotwell, or you could risk 24th and Mission.  But I'd rather not.

I had a Manhattan (a good one, and cheap!) and, I think, a Speakeasy IPA.  And that's a good drink combo for a night in the Mission.  Screw PBR, keep your money local . . .

But watch your head going into the bathroom.  It's very easy to hit your head if you're over 6', and do you really want to be the guy half in and out of the bathroom, passed out?  That won't be a good or gentle night.  You'll surely end up on their Yelp or Myspace page, probably with a dog lapping your face . . .
author: Joe B.

description:
Love, love, love it!  It's like a little slice of the old West in the Mission, of all places!  You walk in and immediately hear the crunch of peanut shells beneath your feet.  The old register glitters with gold & silver, perfectly matching the parquet gold ceiling.  The wallpaper is similar to what you'd find in an old hotel lobby with elaborate patterns and it's jazzed up with a few portraits of partially nude women.  The lemon drop was delish but the bloody's really did it for me... spicy and garnished with pickled green beans and green tomatillos.  The service was a little sub-par... they have a bar-back that is hardly busy but can't do a thing for you and the one bartender working on a Friday night is pretty slow and selective. But the Homestead is great change of pace, that's for sure.

Drink of choice:  the bloody bloodies!!  A meal in a glass : )
author: Tara G.

description:
Ok, here's the thing. 

This place is entirely way too white. And not even in the m]Mission "I am a bohemian white". But in the Marina cheap designer/post college kind of way.

I order the 7th drink and I didn't even slur my words. The drinks were weak and watered down. I blame the bartender and wanted another but she was the only one.  I use to be a bartender and that was no 4 count she was pouring.  I don't need to have a roofie in a glass (although I might like it) but I would like to walk home with a good buzz.

Not all was bad. I did appreciate the old saloon style bar and throwing peanut shells on the ground. 

but, not my cup of roofie..
author: Manuel M.

description: I just learned the bar peanuts I always stuff in my purse are not free. No wonder no one likes me here! I still can't stay away though.
author: Rebecca P.

description:
Usually after several glasses of wine, it's not a wise idea to go for the hard liquor, but upon entering here, I had to. It was a Saturday night (I guess that makes it alright) and it was around 10pm--and there was a SEAT at the bar for myself and all my friends. I almost fell out of it when I realized the luck.

We ARE in the Mission, right? Right.

I'm never in this particular nook and cranny of the woods, and was glad to have stumbled upon this place before a crazy Mission party. There were men in hats and Mr. Rogers sweaters. Puppies. People playing cards. Velvet boobie paintings on the walls and peanuts. Peanuts on the floor! On the bar! On the chairs by the door! 

Did I mention the cheap drinks? Um, yeah. We had  several.

Friendly service, neighborhood bar. Don't come here. I mean it.
author: Jessica P.

description: This place is legit! Small and cozy yet not too crowded. Peanuts on the bar and descent drinks. A lot of other people griped about the service but I didn't seem to have an issue. I will go back for sure!
author: Shanna T.

description:
Legend has it that this place used to be a brothel back in the day.

Evidence includes the high tin ceilings, the divey/sketchy atmosphere, the nudes on the wall that ride the fine line between art and soft-core porn, and quite a bit of wishful thinking on the part of my drinking companions who advanced this theory over a few beers.

More recently, this place was Dylan's, which I assume was named after Dylan Thomas, as evidenced by the words "Do not go gentle into that good night. Rage, rage against the dying of the light" painted on the mantle.

I think they should have put his famous last words on the mantle instead: "I've had 18 straight whiskies. I think that's the record."

Although, like any good reviewer, I checked my facts with Wikipedia, and apparently those were not Dylan Thomas' actual last words but rather some words he said soon before he died. Nevertheless, I am going to continue to believe that they WERE his last words. Also that Homestead used to be a brothel. 

I have noted in some of my previous reviews that I really like to drink in uncrowded, unpretentious bars on random weekdays. This bar is right up my alley. I just wish they had a slightly better selection of darker beers on draught. And some prostitutes upstairs.
author: Liz G.

description: Dude, how have I never noticed this place before?  Shame on me.  I am curious how long this place has been here. Looks like forever. Great early 1900 devote and bar. Can't wait to go back
author: Jim B.

description:
There's a lovely private room in the back to throw a little party. A GIANT dog named Sweet Pea will startle you. Monday happy hour features $1 miller. WTF? ONE DOLLAR?

This place is alright.
author: Vidya S.

description:
ripe after two tumblers 
he gambled with a glass
of tall nostalgia
and started hyphenating
the conversation
 
the connections were senseless
and slid to the floor
joining the residual peanut shells
collecting around his stool
tracking the length of his stay
 
this girl with the freckles
next to him, high
was smiling like she cared
trying to dissect his speech
and encourage him to continue
 
they were quite a pair
those two
they were always there
like this.
author: Kristen K.

description: This is my neighborhood bar and been coming to this spot for 15 years, starting when it was Dylan's. It's a great bar with good down to earth drinks, a rocking jukebox, slobbering dogs and a fabulous mix of multi-generational  folks who are always friendly. I would however, like to see some paintings of hot naked men to balance out the ones of the naked woman that are staged around the walls. Also, the peanuts for a buck are a plus, but you will get told off--nicely-- if you DON'T throw the shells on the floor. The tiny back room is great to rent for a private party.
author: Uda W.

description:
1 star for free peanuts that you can throw on the floor
1 star for the pre-tv era wallpaper
1 star for having tried my first glass of macallan whiskey. 

3 solid stars with tax and hyper-inflation = 4 so-so stars. 

Call your local senators to vote against the bailout bill! Either way I'll probably be here on Thursday next week to sulk about the state of the economy.
author: Jae K.

description:
The Phone Booth will always be my first love, but Homestead is starting to win my heart as the kind of place I want to make my bar.

Off the beaten path enough to weed out the B&T crowd and obnoxious hipsters from the Valencia corridor?  Love it.

Secret former-speakeasy or something-else-cool room with leather-padded walls where they keep the kegs?  Nice touch.

Giant (seriously) dog that puts his paws on the bar and pretends he's people?  Kinda scary, but okay.

Big enough to sit comfortably at a table with six friends but small enough to still be able to hear each other talk?  Just what I'm looking for.

Gold-plated molding on the ceiling?  Makes me feel so classy.

Makers and ginger for $5??!?!?  Don't mind if I do.  Do not mind at all.
author: Megan D.

description: jack and coke is not a well drink here!!! hahaha... i laugh!!!!! def not coming here for happy hour again. twooo stars solely for the historical/vintage environment!
author: Ashlen A.

description: Two of us on Friday after work bike tour of Mission first stop.  Dressed in mountain bike shorts and shirt. Bar was crowded but not packed.  Two friendly bar tenders greeted us with glasses of water.  Seemed knowledgeable about their inventory.  Enjoyed a  Rye Manhattan, friend drank a shot of Templeton and a shorty bottle of beer.  Discarded peanut shells on the floor per bartender.  Classic salon ambience.  Would have liked to stay for another but it was the beginning of our bar tour.
author: T F.

description:
They have a 3 paintings of the same girl topless.  

Great hipster bar with affordable beers - went from quiet to packed from 9pm to 10pm Friday.
author: Paul K.

description:
The strangest thing happened to me the last time I was here. 

It was at the end of an epic night that started as a large group but was down to just three of us. It was about half way through May and it was cold outside. Into Homestead walked a girl wearing nothing but a bra and a skimpy low rise skirt with a guy dressed as a Circus Ringmaster. Even more surprisingly the people I was drinking with knew these guys and the next thing I know nearly naked girl plunks down right at our booth and starts chatting. I think all of us were a little out of it but someone commented on the skirt and Brazilians and the girl pulled the skirt down and flashed us her junk. The Circus Ringmaster didn't like that much and shouted "get up we're going to Shotwell's" but nearly naked girl just ignored him. It was after last call anyway, unless they were having a lock in party he wasn't going to get a drink there anyway. I was so unsure that this really happened I had to check with my friends later.

This is a decent bar that gets crazy busy sometimes. They have some very very rare whiskeys in a special case but expect to pay a premium for them.
author: Manny F.

description: Been hearing a lot about this place from all kinds of friends in SF. The owners and staff take good care of you, and the bar has a super friendly and welcoming vibe. If I lived in San Francisco, I'd be a regular!
author: Karin C.

description: Definitely underestimated this bar. This place is in a very easy to find, corner location that has a lot of character. The decor, wallpaper, and paintings are very unique and classy. Being a small bar that is often packed, it's not as easy to find a table/seat, but many people stand up anyway and tend to linger. The beer selection is magnificent - many beers that you will rarely find on tap, or available at any bar for that matter. They also have PBR cans for only 2 bucks, in case you're trying to be frugal. The atmosphere and patrons are very chill, friendly people. You got your combination of neighborhood hipsters and people stopping by for a drink after work. I met someone here whom I had only met once before, so it's a perfect meeting spot whether it's with somebody who's out of town, or going out for a date.
author: Anthony L.

description:
Pros: Fast, efficient bartenders, who make pretty good cocktails. Full bar with a decent selection of Scotch (considering you're in the Mission). Decent prices and they take credit cards (again, not always a given in the Mission). Relatively high ratio of cute girls. Cool paintings of nude women on the walls.

Cons: Sparse seating. Poor ventilation (it got really hot in there). No barbacks picking up empties or wiping up spills. High noise level when it's a full house.

I was there on a Saturday night and it was pretty crowded. Irritatingly crowed, as a matter of fact. They had someone at the door checking IDs, but they weren't regulating the crowd so I had lots of people bumping into my drink or pushing me to get through. It's a cool bar and I'd love to go back on a night that's not so crowded.
author: Scott S.

description:
(Pub Commute Stop 2)

If, as they say, a locovore's
a wise man and a thrifty,
why must he pay 12 dollars for
a shot of Anchor's whiskey?

Seriously, Old Potrero is temptingly local but prohibitively expensive.  But how could I resist?  I needed something historical to match the atmosphere.

If you recognize the rhyme, you'll probably like Homestead.  Is it actually a recreation of some old San Francisco vibe?  I doubt it--it used to be called Dylan's (after the Welshman, not the Minnesotan), and it seems like the kind of place he would have frequented (not that I know what I'm talking about, mind you).  And that tin ceiling?  I kind of liked it, Ed's disapproval notwithstanding.

Overall, it was easily the high point (venue-wise, anyway) of the pub commute, and an instant addition to my drinking short-list.  Since it's a neighborhood bar, it was actually quite busy even on Tuesday, but it's not that hard to get to (just 2 long blocks from Bruno's, if you want to trade in cool-cat retro for warm-and-toasty-fireside retro).

So with the double warmth of spirits and fireplace in us, off we go (and none too gentle) into that good night...
author: Wes M.

description:
there's not much around this location, but that's somewhat of the allure. i parked across the street and cruised right on in.

cool bartenders, great selection, big dogs walking around (like really big), and old school topless paintings hung on the very high walls.

this place captures the sf spirit, i like it.
author: Ameer N.

description: Finally made it by this place after wanting to check it out many times.  It's a pretty sweet bar with a low key vibe and no pretentiousness at all.  inside it feels warm and comfy but still has a saloon-y old time feel.  Since I was on a bar brawl (= bike bar crawl) my visit was far too brief, so I am looking forward to coming here again with friends.   A great spot to chill if you wanna avoid the amateurs that are often at so many other Mission bars.
author: Gene X.

description:
Discovered this place walking from Mission Cliffs to Cellspace. A very long scooter was parked outside (wish I had gotten a picture of it. I described it as a scooter limo, but my friend described it as a scooter hearse), and the windows had a warm glow, perhaps from the people more than the lights. Had to take as step inside.

Classy saloon decor, without trying too hard to be hip like bourbon and branch. Staff was attentive and friendly. Wasn't hard to get a drink despite it being crowded. Good mixed crowd of people hanging out, and having a good time. Roasted peanuts are addictive. The drink prices are up to (or perhaps down to) Mission standards, which is a definite plus. 

Good selection of whiskies! Enjoying Lagavulin with some friends on a rainy Friday near a wood burning stove at Homestead. What could be better?
author: Boris C.

description: Bartender was super friendly here and was the best part of the bar. We went in early so it was very quiet but not terrible. It is a bit of a jog off of the typical mission bar hoping experience.
author: Casandra R.

description: The private room in the back is the best thing about this bar. Have a party in there, but the only thing is you have to bring your own music. It's better for conversation and just hearing the music from the bar faintly in the background.
author: Myla A.

description:
When I found the homestead it was like a true awakening. that or it was the massive amounts of liquor. Either way you can't go wrong with this place. 

It was away from the hustle and bustle from the rest of the bars and/or annoying kids in the mission. Off the beaten path and had i not been brought, probably never knew it existed. 

Everything from the bartenders right down to the old timey decor. This place is great! And definitely worth the visit for a drink or ten! Plenty of seating and good for groups of friends. New and old.
author: California G.

description:
Its almost not fair for me to review Homestead.  Even though I live across town, I consider it my local.  I love it despite how popular and crowded its become. 

Everyone behind the bar is a superstar.  They are all smart, friendly, fun people who do thier best to make sure you get served quickly.  It doesn't matter if you are a regular or not.  

The jukebox is loaded with an unusual collection of music from all genres.  They dont have a lot of the typical "bar room greatest hits."  This is a plus!  Anyone who really loves music should have no problem finding tunes to play.

Cocktails are made fresh and from scratch.  The bloody mary mix is made by hand.  Margaritas contain fresh juice.  The booze selection is impressive and comprehensive.

There is usually some kind of drink special going on like, late night happy hours or deep discounts on selected specialty booze.  On Thursday nights during the regular afternoon happy hour, if you choose to pay full price for your drink, the extra dollar or so goes to charity.

Thursday and Friday nights can be crowded, noisy, and uncomfortable.    Saturday nights are either slam packed or quiet.  Weeknights are best, especially Mondays when the Shellack Shack dj brings in his collection of  78s.
author: Miss Information X.

description:
Had been to this place quite a few times before, but last night's experience makes me never want to go back again. Met up with a couple friends for a chill Thursday evening drink - they were already there, and my friend and I arrived and I ordered 2 drinks at the bar. I was asked for ID (for the first time ever at that bar), so I obliged even though I thought it was weird. Then the bartender insisted that she see a 2nd ID for the other drink, and my friend, who had just gotten off a flight from London, had left her passport at home. The waitress then insisted that we leave the "establishment," despite our suggestion that my friend doesn't get a drink and we just hang. I was quite calm and asked if she'd really checked everyone's ID in the bar. She didn't answer and went to get another bartender (I believe could be the same one that appears in the other bad review below), who said that they check everyone's IDs. My friends confirmed no one had checked theirs. I ask her "so if I call the cops and have them come and check everyone's IDs here, you're sure everyone will pass?" to which she replies "well you can do that but you need to leave my establishment right now." 

I should have placed a call, but figured the cops have better things to do than tend to the whims of some arrogant and discriminatory bartenders. If you want the chill local neighborhood-y bar experience, which this place USED to provide, just walk 2 blocks away from it and go to Shotwell's. Much much friendlier & more fun atmosphere, and less stuck up than the overly entitled ego-boosted individuals behind the bar at Homestead.
author: Raja H.

description: I may have a check in here, but we promptly left when 1) it wasn't our scene and 2) there wasn't a table. My girl friend and I just wanted a night cap, and the eclectic groups of people eying up our outfits lead us to believe they probably wouldn't be pulling a chair out for us to join. Ahhh, another time!
author: Kristin F.

description:
Guess I wasn't in the loop when Dylan's closed.  So imagine my surprise when I showed up there to get a drink with some friends.  No Dylan's!  Instead, Homestead.

Well...the name is different.  And all the crazy stuff on the walls has been replaced with gold and maroon wallpaper on which hangs two different portraits of the same naked lady.  

Everything else pretty much the same.  Same bar, same round tables, same fire burning in the pot-bellied stove, same liquor and beer selection and same laid-back neighborhood crowd.  This is a nice unpretentious place to chill and chat with some friends, but I wouldn't go out of my way to go unless I happened to be in the area.
author: Emily L.

description:
A cool little local bar in the middle of nowhere... which is exactly where we (yes, the royal "we") need to be sometimes.  

Nowhere, by the way, is about 9 blocks away from me, and was a perfect little stop after dinner this past Friday evening.  Good beer, good service, a nice crowd, and yet not too crowded.  And they have Pimms... the taste of the social summer yet to come.
author: Akshay S.

description: We came across this bar as we were walking in the neighborhood and it was a great find.  The place was packed so you knew it was going to be good.  It was decorated very cool and it was actually pretty easy to get drinks even though it was so crowded.  The best part is that they serve peanuts.  BUT the best part of our night is when they ran out of peanuts and a girl came from across the bar and stole our basket of peanuts.  You know who you are ;)  So you know they must be good or they just serve really strong drinks if that's the affect they have on people.
author: Blake B.

description: Great atmosphere, $2 beers backed with rare whiskeys and excellent manhattans, what more could you ask for?
author: M L.

description: Dang!  Homestead knew how to turn a dull & tiring Tuesday night into a fun, all is great in life, type of night!  I actually was totally wiped out and did not want to even go out, but my roommates and I had made plans weeks ago so in order not to flake, I dragged my but out the door.  That was the best thing I could've done.  The bar was totally worth it.  Like what Carolyn B. said, it has character and a distinctive decor, which makes you feel like you're in an old English pub w/a lot of charm.  Our bartender, Deb, was incredibly nice and made us feel like regulars in our neighborhood bar.  We were also entertained by Sweet Pea, a ginormous boul mastif, who stole the show in the place, she was really entertaining.  The Spanish Fuente del Conde wine that I had was great too.  I look forward to going back.
author: Swetha G.

description:
When I was little, growing up in the Old Country, there was this place everybody referred to as "the living room". Of course "the living room" was actually a bar, and we were all pretentious teenagers (simmer down, drinking laws are different over there...) sneaking out of school in the afternoon and hanging out at the bar over a pint instead. For many years I did indeed spend more hours in that bar than at home, and it always felt safer and more comfortable than my apartment.

Many years have passed since (more than I care to remember), and ever since leaving home I've been searching for that perfect "living room": lived in, yet not too grungy, comfortable but not to posh, easy-going, with a good clientele you can love or leave and sensible barkeeps. 

Well, I may have found it when I first walked into the Homestead the other day....

*cue happy ending violin track*
author: Tatjana G.

description:
A hidden Gem...went here last night with Bunny and the Gang to meet some friends. Never packed and the staff is wonderful too. It tends to be busier on Friday and Saturday nights but usually only the local crowd. 

Great cocktails and peanuts galore...
author: Teddy d.

description:
Out of all the bars in the Mission, this is one of the best. An old bar (over 100 years) with awesomely-tacky decor, this place wins for their liquor, prices, and for the fact that it's reliably quiet enough that you can actually go to talk with friends. It will fill up on a Friday or Saturday, but not as quickly as other Mission bars, and there are still often seats to be had. It's a bit off the beaten path, which keeps it from getting too crowded and encourages a mostly local crowd.

The Homestead stocks a solid liquor selection, especially their whiskies and gins. Whenever there's a new local spirit hitting the market or coming in vogue, I often see it here before anywhere else. The bartenders usually know their stuff, and the prices they charge are very reasonable. They've got a decent selection on tap as well, though not an especially notable one.

The jukebox here is good and eclectic. They have peanuts at the bar and encourage you to toss the shells on the floor. Plenty of seating. Cozy, warm, and just an all-around great place. This isn't the place to go when you're looking for a high-energy, dance-y spot, but among relaxed, chatty bars, the Homestead will make a place in your heart like none other.
author: Rick B.

description:
So I went to this bar for the first time last night and ordered a beer from the female bartender.  I didn't hear how much it was, so I gave her two fives assuming that would definitely cover it.  I never got any change.  I waited a bit and then politely asked if I gave her one five or two, and she told me she thought it was a 5 and a 1, she didn't know.  Then she brought over her tip jar and said I could have the change out of her tips.  I tried to give her the benefit of the doubt and said fine, you keep all the change, and we ended up splitting it down the middle.  It was a saturday night, but it was only 9:30 and not very crowded yet, and this was my first drink of the evening.  She ended up making me feel awkward and sh%^tty for the rest of the night, as if i was stealing from her pocket.  I didn't want to deal with her again and had my friend order my next drink for me.  I don't care that it was a divey bar on a weekend, there should still be some moderate level of customer service and respect.  I had such a bad experience that I will avoid going back to this place.

Otherwise it seemed like a great bar.  There was a dog there, the crowd seemed ok, the bathrooms were clean, so its a real shame.

Wow, just noticed that Heather C. also reviewed the bar very similarly, loving everything except the female bartender.
author: Corey p.

description: I've only been here after 1AM, but I'm definitely a fan.  It has a nice chill atmosphere, peanuts on the floor, and plenty of seating.  Bartenders were super cool, although that might have had something to do with a certain team in black and orange winning some really important game over some team from Texas that night.
author: Jason T.

description:
With its shiny tin ceilings, fresh wallpaper and wood-burning stove, Homestead looks just like a brand-new bar, but from a hundred years ago. There's kind of a time-travel effect when you walk in, like you half expect to see a DJ with a handlebar mustache standing between to giant Victrolas (but in a good way...). 

Anyway, for a great evening on a cold, foggy night, here's the hot tip: pick up friend/date, grab a burrito from the truck on Harrison, a block away. (I know--I wouldn't have believed it either but some of the best burritos I've had have come from this very truck.) Anyway, grab said burritos and head to Homestead, have a couple of pints and have dinner in front of the toasty fire. For a cas. evening out, it's a goody.
author: Nik S.

description:
I really, really liked it. 
Both times I went the bar was pretty empty.  Dog to my left and peanut shells on the floor.  It feels like an old saloon and looks like one too.  It is a good thing I don't live nearby or this would be my second home.  Bonus points for still having the mini millers.  I am sure it would be a different experience if the bar was really jammed up, but it wasn't.  Prices were avg. with plenty of cheap options.  The cool little details are what make this place a true gem, too many to list.
author: Justin N.

description:
Superclose to home + peanuts on the floor + HOT TODDIES!!

What more could a lady ask for on these rainy days??
author: Michelly S.

description:
I love a neighborhood bar with no television. I love a neighborhood bar with funky wallpaper and a shiny ceiling. it reminded me of a eighteenth-century London pub, without the bangers. i love a neighborhood bar with paintings of breasts on the walls. breasts, I say. who's against breasts?

the floor was covered with peanut shells, which made me feel kind of tough. as though there had been a hoe-down brawl right before I got there.
author: Nato G.

description:
I'm going to use this review to correct a few misconceptions about this place.  I guess I'm feeling a little defensive because I liked it so much:

1)  There is PBR - in cans.
2) Not a misconception - but they also carry the Juniper Gin from Anchor Steam which is *the* most delicious gin in the world.  In fact, it is the only gin I will drink.
3) Though I dislike virtually all animals, especially dogs, the "open dog" policy is not out of control at Homestead.  On a crowded Saturday night, there was only one, very chill dog in the place.  I kind of liked that dog, which is really saying something coming from the daughter of a mailman.
4)  You can play some kind of dice game to win a pool of money - also not a misconception, but cool.
5)  The music in the jukebox is eclectic and awesome, not strange.  I've never been in a bar with Mahalia Jackson and other old timey gospel selections and I fully support their inclusion.

All in all, this place is faaaantastic.
author: Katina M.

description:
Great bar to meet friends after work and before you go home or go out for the night. Drinks are reasonably priced and the free peanuts are a nice touch.

The bar space gets crowded on Thursdays and Fridays, so be prepared for a small wait to get your drinks, but the wait is worth the ambiance.
author: Kenny W.

description:
When you think of the word "homestead", you have certain expectations and things that pop up in your mind when imagining such a place:

Comfort - The place is nice and spacious with barstools or a few tables and chairs.  

Warmth - Yeah a beer blanket or whiskey is nice to keep warm, but how about a raging fire in the corner on a chilly December night while you enjoy your beer or whiskey?

A good drink - The bartenders here make 'em good and aren't scared of chatting it up a little.  The beer selection is decent and depending on your budget you can load up on Tecate or throw back a few of the Christmas brews.  

Awesomely enough this place feels kind of like an unused living room area somewhere in your grandpa's house.  I've found homestead a consistently good place to come a have a relaxed drink.  

I guess the only other thing that would make this truly home would be my mom taking a ham out of the oven after about 7 beers.
author: Steven R.

description:
i just remembered ive been here. how i ended up here is a blur, and living in the mission for years I never ever knew of it's existence until the night I ended up there. I even made out with my now ex boyfriend there.but i digress.

this place is nice. upscaleish without losing it's Mission bar charm.i should go back here. drinks are reasonable price wise
author: Lauren V.

description:
Some say im frivolous with my star distribution, others would say I have nothing bad to say...others say..SAY....
 
I want to start with a little tale of a Salvadorean boy growing up in the Mission. Growing up I would always walk past this place on my way to Elementary school on 18th and South Van Ness, its still there check it out St. Charles.  At any rate, It was Dylans at one point...and it was the epitomy of Yuppy town, I knew that when i turned 21 what ever part of the world i was at, I would come in just to start a bar fight....At the age of 23 I ventured into this place, but only now it was The Homestead. A homage to its early century Brothel legacy....I dropped all animosity and embraced the the peanut shells, the dogs walkin about, the beer and the local watering hole...I salute you Homestead, You know how to make a good Jack and Coke and maintain that Mission Vibe like its supposed to be... Suit and Tie optional
author: Joe J.

description: Great no nonsense bar with a cool old school vibe and nice beers on tap.  Great music, good vibe, and cool atmosphere.  If you were going to create a good bar to drink in, it doesn't get a lot better than this in my opinion.  I haven't been late at night, only for an afternoon weekend drink, but I hope to be back.
author: Sean H.

description: Amazing vibe, people and drinks. This laid back bar's decor harks back to pubs of 100 years ago, but stripped down. Gold ceilings and pendant lamps that look like they were stolen from a train station create a warm and friendly ambiance. But don't worry this place has edge with naughty pin-up oil paintings and hip but not in your face hipsters. Delicious Tom Collins and a number of beers on tap. Clean bathrooms too.
author: Jacqueline S.

description:
Weeelll, it is a nice crowd of mixed unemployed, unemployable and regulars. Hipster plus not. Over 40 and way NOT. 

But my friend who is a bit of a connoisseur of tequila got a 1/2 for her first shot. Short shots only work in muggings, oy, sorry. Admittedly the very nice bartender overheard her and gave her a second shot for free (and yes we did pour it in the original glass and yes, it was a way short shot.) My marguerita was nicely fresh lime juiced per my request but if there was any tequila in there, I missed it. Both were $6/USD.

Ambiance is old western saloon. I say that with some authenticity bc my dad comes from Meeteetse, WY. I spent a couple of nights last summer in a saloon in Cody, WY and they had the same pressed tin ceiling. The Homestead has way more tasteful naked ladies on the wall. VEWY sexy. 

I would give it a second chance, esp since parking is pretty easy on a weeknight.
author: Miel H.

description:
This place is beautiful on the interior - looks like something from Tombstone Arizona!  Prices are okay, and the people were mixed. I do have a complaint about a bartendress - she forgot about my order. My $10 sat on the bar for four or five minutes, and then when I saw her draw someone else's beer, I was like "Benders isn't that far away." They are dog friendly which is a bonus.
EPILOGUE: I went back and the bartendress this time was good to great. Not a lot of beautiful people, but I guess that's the Mission for ya! (D'OH!)
author: Jason M.

description:
When bars change I am the first one to say I probably wont go anymore. 
New owners will bring in new staff, disrespects the ideas of regulars, and jacks up the prices of drinks.
Well the Homestead made a believer out of me !!!
Best staff ever !! Cheap drinks and good booze, and they truly get the understanding of keeping regulars happy (and new patrons coming back)! 
I have not seen a bar that treats the community with such great respect.

I think the location must be sitting on top of some kind of ancient prospect spot, since every bar that has been there, is a gold mine in my book !
author: krispy k.

description: Best bar in the area. Great bartenders. Depending on the night the clientele can be a little douchey though.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
For some reason, I find myself drawn to saloon style bars with naked ladies on the walls.  Perhaps it's because I'm secretly a cowboy from the mid 18th century transplanted to the present day.  Perhaps it's because hidden among a school and a firehouse, I enjoy the idea of a unique bar (how many other saloons are there in the mission I ask you?) that I can find a table at midnight. Perhaps I just enjoy naked ladies.

You be the judge.
author: Nelson A.

description: Homestead actually makes a proper old fashioned.  It's my measuring stick for bars and bartenders.  Not full of soda water and fruit salad. Fairly reasonably priced to boot. Not over crowded.  Bathroom is civilized.  Nuff said.
author: Chris Y.

description: This is exactly the kind of bar you want in your neighborhood, with good beers on tap, classic liquors as well as unusual ones (saffron-infused gin!), a fine jukebox, nice bartenders, and peanut shells on the floor. A treasure.
author: Jonas L.

description:
Despite the saloon-ish leanings, this place makes me feel a little bit like I'm back in London drinking at my local.  They even serve Fuller's beer.  ::sigh::  Best of all, this IS my local now!  Lucky me.  

Bonus points to Homestead for having a live DJ playing very enjoyable music... without setting it so loud you couldn't hear your companions talking.  I don't think we even had to raise our voices at all.  So much love.
author: Jess L.

description: Love it!  Cheap drinks, good crowd and great bartenders.  They have free peanuts and you can throw the shells on the floor.   I was here this past Saturday night and I hate crowded bars on the weekends.  I avoid them like the plague.  This place was not bad though.  Crowded and a little warm, but I still had a great time.  The bartenders are on it!
author: Corey V.

description: As a sucker for nice scotch and warm atmosphere, Homestead has never steered me wrong. I love running into my neighbors, enjoying the mostly-great music, and spending too much money here.  The vintage vibe is refreshing, and it is far enough from Mission Street that it retains the feel of the perfect neighborhood bar that it is.
author: Tracy B.

description:
The Homestead is like  a warm blanket, it wraps it's boozy goodness around you and keeps you safe and comfy all night long. 

I was very impressed the first time I walked in to this tiny little bar in the middle of nowhere, or so it appears at night. The dj they had that night was playing very nice, old music that fit the place perfectly. Not too loud and obnoxious, just a little mood music. 

I kinda get that small town feeling here. The bartenders are super cool and some people even pop in to have a beer with their dog. It's all very cute. 

I suggest that you avoid the Homestead as much as possible. That way it will remain the quaint, hip little bar that it is today.
author: Amanda B.

description:
If only this place were actually in my 'hood. But it's worth the trek if you aren't in the Mission. What a great spot. Warm and inviting, chill atmosphere, nice bartenders - I was holding my friend's dog in my lap only to look up and see one bartender holding a dog biscuit for our furry friend in her hand. And us non canines get served with a smile too.

The only thing that makes me sad about this place is the thought of the poor person who has to clean up the peanut shells littering the floor.
author: Tara B.

description: I guess it depends on what bartender you're dealing with. I've had some great experiences at this place but on a few occasions I've found myself seriously underwhelmed.
author: Jorge H.

description:
really fun place - it's got really cozy decor, friendly bartenders and just a great spot to get a breath of fresh air from the rest of the Mission bar-hoppers.  even when it gets crowded, it's still full of other mellow people who are just enjoying their local watering hole for some drinks and good chat.  

my only complaint is that the smell is quite offensive upon entering... (ie as if someone had pissed all over the floor) BUT it was pouring rain outside, so that may have been something to do with it.....but after a few drinks, you don't even notice!
author: Tara H.

description: Great dive bar without the diveyness. Fun people, good beer, relaxed atmosphere. All around a good time!
author: Patrick S.

description:
It's hard to write a review for the Homestead because one of the things that makes it so fantastic is the fact that it's our local, relatively hidden watering hole. While we're only a few blocks from the madness of Valencia corridor, you'd barely realize it once you step foot into the dark wood and gold accents of this timeless bar.

The bar tenders are great - and seem pride themselves on maintaining the bars low-key atmosphere. It's a no bull-shit sort of place with great drinks, a fierce jukebox, and good people.
author: Greg Z.

description: Awesome bar. It has a divey Victorian vibe, they serve peanuts, and it is removed enough from the heavy traffic of the Mission bars that it feels like a hidden gem.
author: brian o.

description:
You and me, doll--we're swell. Settled into seats with our buckles pressed into flesh, jeans hanging loose. I lean over, whispering into your ear, "What'll it be, honey bee?" Slapping your thigh with a spare arm, you insist on a wheat beer, light on the lemon and in a glass fit for melons. I throw you that knowing wink, stepping away and up to the bar, hands laid across the countertop in a stretch for service. This is my fourth time here, a habitual haunt in my dating scene--it starts with an ice-cream, wets itself with a beer, and ends with her plastered over my sheets, yelling, "Oh daddy, won't you please." Yeah, I enjoy the joint, it gets the job done. The room itself is a cheap thrill, complete with beefy women and effeminate men, usually together. Always dogs about too. Some lady has her mutt lashed to the bottom rung of a bar stool tonight; she gives me a firm look as it gets a whiff of my crotch and goes digging. 

"Bitch must be in heat," I blurt back, staring at her as the words let fly.
author: Marc M.

description:
So i must admit when i first saw this place i was  a little hesitate, all i saw were men, so i figured maybe i wouldn't really find any interesting people there. Not to mention it looked like a somewhat of a hole in the wall though i do not mind hole in the wall bars but i just wasn't like the vibe i got when i walked pass there on my way home(which is literally only a block away).

My roomies and i try to grab a drink together once a month so we decided to check out Homestead because it was so close. I walk in my first thought is ok...there aren't really any good looking guys in here,  which leads me to my second thought..hmm..that must be why the lighting is so funky, and ah that's why i never see too many women in here.

We take a seat the bar, the bartender(Deb) ask for our ids and then ask us what we 'd like to order. my roomie Swetha and i both really love wine, so Swetha asked her what kind of wine selection they had..and Deb came back with about five bottles of wine and said these are the only ones but you guys can try each one if you'd like...AWESOME...WE LOVE DEB!

As the progressed it got crowded, turns out someone was having some kind of after party type thing, and i think maybe it was someone that worked there..whom i hate to say i don't think i liked her much but only because she knew that Deb was the only one working and she brought alot of people in there and poor Deb was working her ass off, yet this girl would occasionally come back there in help, i mean yes i know she wasn't working but how would she feel if someone did that to her? None the less Deb handled it with Grace.

I liked the bar..ill be back again on a Tuesday Friday or Sunday. I really like the vibe i got once i was in there..it was like your friendly neighborhood bar, and the bathroom was clean..you got love that.
author: Nia W.

description:
good for dogs. perfect getaway from typical mission crowds. 

one of the oldest bars in town. gets great light in the afternoon and has free peanuts to chuck on the floor.

lots of scooter and film aficionado types it seems.
author: Crutonic L.

description: I was surprised that I hadn't been to this place until now.  According to my Mission friends the crowd is Mission Hipsters but I didn't mind.  It has a good local feel to it -- a place you can hang out.  Good selection of drinks, good music, good bar tender and beautiful people.
author: M. B.

description: Came here for a birthday. They had standard drinks, so I'm reviewing more for the vibe if you're feeling social. The space felt like a cramped living room in the boondocks; walking through the crowd, l was like Moses in a sea of parting flannel shirts, but milieu was generally unassuming and intimate. My friends had rented out the back room, which felt like a time capsule of sorts--a good get-away from the grouchy bartenders and flannel shirts. Wish I saw the resident dog, but the boobs on the wall seemed very conducive to pick-up lines.
author: Nicole L.

description:
Just moved into this neighborhood:
Peanuts
GARGANTUAN slobbering dog
Stiff drinks 
$20 private room
Accepts plastic $$$ to add to my already-soaring drinking debt
Music=meh, could be better could be A LOT worse
Vintage titties
Ample seating
Concerned bartenders of street cleaning violators
Really high,  mesmerizing ceiling to drunkenly fade off into.....

You'll be seeing me around!
author: Jessica U.

description:
Gold celings, cool wall decor, great bartenders
& mini doorways!
Good beers on tap.
Not too crowded.
Decent jukebox.
go
author: A S.

description:
I was only in Homestead for about an hour, but I did get to see the famous big dog put his paws on the countertop... he looked like a rottweiler mastiff mix; black w/ caramel marbeling? 

Anyway, Homestead. I really liked the people who worked there. The crowd was a slightly older skew, and I, being under 30 was most likely the youngest person there. It did give me hope for humanity however, because there were really good people there. Genuinely nice. There may have been a prick or two but if they were they kept to themselves and didn't try to show it. If I lived nearby I might stop in once a week. 

I did also notice helmets resting on the piano in the corner. Naturally I assumed they belonged to the motorcycle-esque crowd, however they did belong to what looked like a scooter gang: no one was dressed alike, nothing like that, but there were four scooters parked outside when I stepped out to make a quick call. 

Cool place to hang out. Agreed: "no fuss, no fronting." which is a very refreshing quality.
author: Stephanie D.

description:
i don't know, its pretty neat here.  peanuts are cool to shell and shuck on the ground.  the naked lady paintings everywhere were rad until i got all up in their girl grills and realized that they were just posters.  people were running around saying they only paid 3 bucks for their hefeweizen. good deal, but i got myself a boddington's which was on tap! 
so, yep, check it out!  it san francisco history!
author: yayoi s.

description: Went to dinner with my girlfriend at Heirloom Cafe and wanted to grab a drink(s) after.  Asked the cute waiter 'what's a cool, chill bar to go to for drinks?' and he said Homestead.  Great reco.  Loved the bar and the bartender was really friendly, even after i was a big tipsy and asking questions.  I definately want to go back again.  And it's not right in the Mission madness.
author: chloe b.

description:
Comfy local bar just off the mission.  It is a great place to meet friend to chill out or for preparing for a night on the town.
Dont forget to check out the 45's spun on monday night.
author: Shawn L.

description:
No argument when requested for water or restroom access. Restroom clean and easy to locate. Price for peanuts reasonable, with clear instruction for shell disposal. Patient, diplomatic bartender. Unambiguous exit route and polite suggestion for departure time.
5 stars if they put a crackpipe in my mouth next time or give me a free lap dance, but, hey.. let's not be too picky, eh? With this city increasingly unable to decide whether it wants to be a San Jose suburb or some kind of gay version of Salt Lake City, The Homestead is holding its own in good style. Tell them I said 'yeah... whatever'. That should pretty much hit the nail on the head with this place.
author: Josh B.

description: Pretty disappointing bar experience. Tacky nudes on the walls, incompetent bartender. She acted annoyed when I asked if they had a cocktail menu, and them gave me a vodka soda when I'd ordered a vodka tonic. The interior was sort of shabby, which was a shame because the space has definite potential. A extra star for the tin ceiling and cool light fixtures.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Walked in to a Vintage Decor: gold tin ceilings, cool wallpaper, dark wooded bar from the gold rush saloon era. A very laid back, fun place to just hang out and chill. 

The bartenders are great, friendly, fun people who make sure that you get your drinks very quickly.

Overall great, except one thing.......not to sure about the neighborhood's (overally excited pit bull) dog strolling around in the bar on a crowded friday night?!
author: josue p.

description: This is what you would call a local watering hole. It's been around for over a hundred years and doesn't look like it's been remodeled since it first opened. There's nothing trendy or pretentious about it...very down to earth. It has a very 'Mission District' feel. Come here for happy hour on a Friday afterwork to down a few beers and enjoy some laughs and good conversation with friends. I'm a fan.
author: Calvin C.

description:
Great place, so atmospheric. Went on a random Monday. Especially great when the lights dimmed and the swing music started playing. 
Takes you back in time! 

I love the high ceilings, the detail on the wood, the old paintings, and the bowls of peanuts (floor is covered in peanut shells!).
author: Tara S.

description: This is a great place to have a nice get together with friends.  We recently rented the back private room for a birthday party and it was awesome.  first of all - it only cost $25 to reserve the room.  I was not aware that you could still get anything for $25.  It was great to have that little nook to have a few more people together and not have to deal with a crowded bar.  The drinks are strong and the service is really good.
author: cece S.

description:
awesome interior.  the only reason not to love this place would be if you are allergic to peanuts!

thursday nights, theres a dude "mo chedda" making fancy grilled cheese sandwiches outside.  about $5 for an atypical twist on this childhood classic.  he'll come find you inside when your 'wich is ready!

like other places in the mission, it's dog friendly.  bring that best friend, they've got treats for him at the bar.

peanuts are $1, thats my only complaint... kinda dumb but whatever.
author: eric f.

description: Oh I really like this bar. I can't believe it wasn't packed (but that's part of its charm). The wallpaper is wonderful, the pressed tin ceiling  is gorgeous, the bartender friendly, the beer selection vast, and the fireplace in the corner is cozy. Add bowls of peanuts in their shells, easy parking, and not too many people, and you have exactly my kind of bar. Too bad there aren't darts or pool, though.
author: Arwen O.

description:
who knew that when you leave your usual stomping ground there are actually some pretty cool places out there....

great drink specials ($1 PBRers and Olympias), PEANUT fights, a huge beast of a dog who licks up his own drool, a cool bartender, and some great records a' spinnin'....

makes for a perfect Monday night....
author: Andrea F.

description: This was our fourth and final stop on my whirlwind birthday tour of the Mission on a Friday night. I was piss drunk by the time we got here. Lots of cool looking folks mingling with grizzled old timers. The walls and ceiling are very shiny!
author: Nate R.

description: Each evening I have attended Homestead I walk away feeling creatively inspired. Not too many places that happens for me these days without quickly being drowned in drunken cackles and howls when the clock strikes 9pm.
author: Xia F.

description: It's like having an old, favorite bar the first time you walk in the door.  Try their dark n' stormies.
author: Jim S.

description:
The Homestead was my favorite neighborhood bar last summer; great jukebox, great drinks, amazing interior. Even when it was really crowded, everyone was chill and it was still a good time. I didn't go for most of the fall and spring, and now that it's summer again, everything's changed. Super aggressive bouncers (when did the homestead get bouncers?!) who kick folks out ten minutes before close with a full drink on the table (dude; one minute after last call is not the time to pound on tables and throw out patrons) and surly bartender( okay; one woman with a long hair who is ALWAYS working and ALWAYS shitty to every person who comes in) 

What happened to the days of semi-professional, if not polite bartenders, no bouncer, and the homestead acting like a chill neighborhood bar?

Maybe it's just two employee who suck horribly, but they've ruined my favorite bar and I won't be going back.
author: Jeff M.

description: I really dislike the one star rating... but it's absolutely necessary in this case. Homestead is on our radar because my husband worked there years ago when it was Dylan's Bar. The present owners kept the Victorian style bar decor and even the quote from Dylan Thomas (my husband's namesake) above the bar. I was happy to remember how cool this place looked and wondered to myself, "Self, why don't we come here more often?" I was immediately smacked into reality by the rudest, most unfriendly bartender I have ever encountered. She literally threw my drink on the bar so hard that it spilled enough liquid  to soak the drink napkin entirely, leaving me to preside over a puddle of vodka. The bar was mostly empty, so this was not a "rushing bartender" type thing. She mumbled something to husband and slammed his beer down as well. She snatched dollars from our hands and moved to another person at the bar, morphing into Ms. Congeniality, bearing smiles, the idle bar wipe-down and peanuts. I was so appalled I had to stay for more punishment... you know, like watching a train wreck? She's just having a bad day? We ordered a second drink and waited for her "royal" treatment. She did not disappoint. She uttered animalistic grunts in our direction and then Chatty Cathy babble with hipster, stage-right. I probably really pissed her off when I asked her for a strawberry daiquiri next... just to see how nasty she could get. Sounds like other people are fond of this place - but I've never experienced a more miserable person.
author: Megan D.

description: Great dive bar, peanuts on the floor, nude paitings hang discretely on the walls. Convenient big table in the back, and a backroom you can actually reserve for bdays and bachelorette parties ;)
author: Matt W.

description: It's the best bar in San Francisco. The rest is details.
author: Jay B.

description:
this place is low key and chill.  i like it because they have belgian white on tap.  i can't remember the name, but it is the one with the friar on it.  so bonus points for that.  and easy parking.

the only bad thing is it's kind of in the middle of nowhere.  and there's peanut shells all over the floor so they get stuck on your shoes.
author: Josie M.

description: Soild drinking bar in SF (19th/Folsom). 8 dollar Tecate pitchers. Dogs running around. Good vibe. We sat at a table and talked for a couple hours and shared Tecates and Jamesons. A very enjoyable place.
author: Asparagus S.

description: They keep it simple and peanuts on all over the floor. It's a good thing. I like going in there and feeling like I'm in the grown up version of Kilowatt. Good jukebox and parking is great. It's  great way to celebrate a good climb at Mission Cliffs.
author: Bill M.

description: Great bar and cute bartenders, my girlfriend and I went here last night and had a ball. Very friendly crowd and great dcor although I am not sure how I missed the two naked lady pictures.
author: E P.

description:
I am in the school of thought that I will park the Marcusmobile in the first spot I see even if I am far from my destination. I was going to Doc's Clock in the Mission for my Happy Hour/Sock Drive and I parked on 19th and Folson. (which I know is far)
We went to Doc's Clock and Cha Cha Cha and I was trying to streer the crowd to a place near the Marcusmobile because it was late and I wanted to be near my car. They did not believe me when I said there was a place down the way and they thought I was taking them to the place where you get cement fred containers. 
We made our way into Homestead (which I know understand used to be Dylan's) and the five star rating is based on the reaction of my friend's so who happens to be Irish. This is like bringing me to a crab house (most crab out here is rubbish) and he really liked it. Sort of like James Joyce stumbling into the rabbit hole into another dimension. 
For the record I had a Calistoga
author: Marcus R.

description:
Cool neighborhood bar off the beaten and crowded path of the Mission, where hipsters go after they graduate hipster school.
Decor resembles a speakeasy where you might see Humphrey Bogart, James Dean or Ana Nicole walk in.
Yellow hanging lights, velvet wallpaper, dark tones, naked lady paintings and raw tin ceiling (that alone can make almost anyone look good)
Juke box has some stuff you don't hear everyday, Judas Priest, Devo, Def Lepoard, Metallica, I'm sure there was some GoGos and Blondie in there too.
It reminds us of Brooklyn, specifically Brooklyn Social, Park Slope Brewery or some hidden gems in Red Hook
And there were a few ladies who were easy on the eyes if you're into the suicidegirls.com look
It's also within stumblable distance to many late night eats places on Mission/Valencia where you can rapidly boost your triglycerides to unhealthy levels along with the other drunk and drugged frisco revelers.
Now only if it were closer to our crib in SOMA
author: G K.

description:
homestead... 

kitschy... nice bar back and lighting... adorable outside... worn floor. terrific horrible wallpaper and crappy retro tin ceiling.
author: jack w.

description: Imagine Dylans with less lighting, a shiny gold ceiling and Victorian wallpaper, and paintings of naked women...but everything else exactly the same: same bar, same tables and bench, same fire, same crappy plumbing.  Neighborhood crowd and its easy to find a table (plus its my neighborhood).
author: Amy E.

description: A low-key spot to catch up with drink beer, eat peanuts (shells on the floor please) and meet up with friends. It's a little out of the way, but that's kind of what I like about it too.
author: Megan C.

description: I went to Homestead on a Friday night.  The vibe was very Williamsburg, which I do like, even though it is becoming a little too common.  It was very crowded and the music sounded like Charlie Brown's teacher was on the mic, I could not even tell what kind of music it was.  I just heard the sound of people.  People were very nice and polite...trading all F you's for please and thank you's.
author: sophia s.

description: This is another 3.5 kind of place.  Packed.  Loud.  No seating.  A bit of a scene.  Fun decor, but said packedness/loudness made it hard to pay attention to much of anything.  I don't remember the beer selection to be anything too special.  Kind of a cool spot but I'd enjoy it more with a little breathing room.
author: Brian D.

description: I loooooove it here... definitely a bar of choice for me... and I lllooove the dogs!
author: Best M.

description: Great pub & basically my "local", to the extent that I have one. Where else can you get $2 Tecate, roasted peanuts AND regular visits from the Tamale Lady? My pal Chris met his wife here. I usually go after the gym, sometimes before. Grrr.
author: Bowen D.

description: best night to go: monday nights.   $1 beers on monday nights! so necessary for anyone with a case of the mondays
author: Jaide F.

description: Very laid back with a warm atmosphere. Drinks are pretty inexpensive and the bartenders are generally very quick and friendly.
author: Kori M.

description: I really wanted to dislike this bar after it changed hands from one of the greatest bars of all time, Dylan's.  But, for a little cow-poke like me, The Homestead is just fine. You can throw peanuts on the floor here (!!)and they still have the Dylan Thomas quote above the bar to pay homage to the fantastic watering hole which occupied the building before. One curious thing though, the window says the bar has been there since 1902 which isn't true unless 1902 means 2005. Great art work on the walls, a roaring fireplace, nice servers and good customers helps make this cozy bar one of my favorite places to stop over at when I'm prancing through the backstreets of the Mission.
author: Benji T.

description: You know when you know everyone who works at the bar, and when you walk in the bartenders see you and pour your favorite drink for you before you can even ask for it, and you can go there any night of the week and automatically know at lease SOMEONE there, and can hang out comfortably there at any time ... oh yeah and as an extra bonus, the jukebox totally rocks..? Yeah- this is that bar for me.
author: Catherine S.

description: Who can tell me the name of this bar b4 it became the Homestead?
