(my memory fails me, it prolly had a couple names), Anyhow, I do like the look and feel to this place and that it's not on the other two main drags of streets. I like the fact that there weren't any teeny-boppers in here. I also witnessed a guy selling frozen steaks out of a box. How cool is that?
author: wayne s.

description:
The Homestead was stop number three on our happy bike bar crawl through the Mission. I'd heard very good things about it and was happy my brain decided to function at above normal capacity, so I actually remembered I'd heard it was great, remembered it was on Folsom, and then, most importantly, remembered to go there at the proper, convenient, serendipitous time. I never do that. I always find myself drinking at the same old place, bored stiff. Then on my way home I smack myself in the forehead, let loose a mighty D'OH! and realize that I could have spent the whole evening somewhere new and different. 

The Homestead is a little bit like your grandma's house in that pleasant, cozy, non-smelly way. It has pretty fuzzy red wallpaper, lovely wooden details and a sparse yet classy ambiance. The bartender was ever-so sweet and the crowd in the bar were clearly local, neighborhood types and my only complaint about them is that they seemed to fear the jukebox. The Brewer and I were the only ones stepping up to the musical plate. Which I guess isn't all bad. 

Their beer selection doesn't suck, but it ain't great either. But they have a variety of yummy liquid snacks in the pretty bottles behind the bar, and I'll be planning an outing to this little place soon, sans bicycle, and tie one on proper with a couple of 209 martinis.
author: Sage R.

description: not only was the bartender friendly enough to help me with my buddy who was acting like a bit of a jerk but she gave me a free drink and free peanuts and most of all. I just like this place a lot. nothing you can't say that is bad about it.
author: Derek Alistair J.

description: A really great juke box,  friendly people, lots to drink.
author: zachary m.

description: I was really worried when Dylan's got bought out, a hard act to follow after all. The new owners were wise to keep on the best bar staff in the city and to listen to the regulars. The bar is now it's own entity, not Dylan's with a new name and that's cool. I like the decor and vibe (could use a few more o them sexy paintins on the walls) and they're working to make it better all the time. Plus the usual benefits of easy parking and plenty of room to park scooters and motorcycles out front (and they'll let you roll yer bike inside if you get too drunk...so I've heard).
author: Mike Z.

description:
nice jukebox
nice vodkas
nice bartender lady
author: Melanie C.

description: I Love Cathy. And Deb. and stale beef jerky.
author: stephan k.

description: Kind of a quasi saloon stylie bar - fun for people watching.
author: D L.

description: This isn't your typical too-cool-for-school hipster mission bar, which is nice. It's slightly off the beaten path, although not too off, since this was the first time I was greeted by the Tamale lady (which was a nice surprise and only enhanced my experience here.) Nice for a chill Sunday or weeknight. Rustic wooden interior, friendly bartenders, and a decent jukebox. If I had to imagine what a saloon from the 1800s would be like, this place would come to mind.
author: Kelly R.

description:
loves.  came here recently to meet up with an old friend. 

good vibes, good crowd -- but not so packed that we couldn't move. we maneuvered our way into a table that other folks weren't using.  

the lighting was nice and dim. the wallpaper was pretty and old-school. felt like being in a stylish relative's cozy living room (one where you can throw peanut shells all over the floor).  

cool spot, yo.
author: Elle B.

description: Oh, the ceiling.  It's beautiful.  Good times!
author: T-Bone L.

description: I LOVE THIS PLACE!  Awesome music, throw your peanut shells on the floor, cider!  What else do you need??  Wicked, un-snooty atmosphere....just moved in down the road...pretty sure it will become our new local!
author: B P.

description: Is where the peanuts grow on the floor. The beers are fresh and the windows are big. Anything more ?
author: Dario B.

description: though my age would suggest otherwise, I think my days of heavy thinking-er, drinking are done. I get way too annoyed dealing with hipsters that crowd my once favorite spots and end up heading home by 10. Thankfully I've found Homestead, which even on a saturday night wasn't suffocatingly crowded. Staff was cool, crowd was pretty chill. Didn't have to yell to have a conversation which was a nice touch.  One of the cleanest bar bathrooms I've ever been in. Huzzah!
author: Marie W.

description: Whenever at the Homestead, I feel like I'm on a movie set, this place is so classic.  Dive-bar-esqe, cause it's so laid back, but on the flip side it's a gorgeous space.  The peanuts in shell add a certain--I don't want to say "je ne sais quoi", but what the hell.   To put this place over the top, the Monday night special is the best around.  Miller High Lifes for a buck.
author: Charlotte O.

description: Do you like peanuts? I do. Decorative tin ceilings, peanuts, fireplace, dimly lit, and a good place to meet friends and play cards.
author: Christopher C.

description: They are just plain cool. Fast service, moderate prices, and a basket of peanuts, what more do ya want? Plus they are open on Christmas in the afternoon, even better.
author: Chris S.

description: what's better than drinking a perfect manhattan, gazing at old-school nude paintings, and listening to an epic juke box? nothing is better, that's what. i'm a genius stereo-typer, yet cannot quite decide what kind of bar this is. there is something so romantic about that, being able to go somewhere and not know if you're gonna get a room full of hipsters, dads, or douches. i dig it.
author: Marie A.

description:
sometimes all a man needs is a quiet place to have a simple beer, ponder the day, and enjoy some quiet. sometimes all a man needs is an unpretentious bar to hang out with some quality friends. sometimes all a man needs is to hang out at a neighborhood bar with a lot of history and enjoy his surroundings. and sometimes all a man needs is to drown his sorrows in the warmth of some whiskey.

no matter what sort of need you may have, this place is a great location to fulfill it. i prefer wednesday nights after i'm done climbing over at mission cliffs. i have other reasons i prefer wednesday nights, but you'll just have to go in and find out yourself why that may be. the bartenders are attentive (mainly because it's a more quiet joint) and the patrons are usually friendly. un-pretentiousness is a good thing, my friend.
author: Jeremiah W.

description:
this is the kind of bar i'll the husband to and he'll be like, i'm so glad we found this place, and i'll say, actually i've been her before. and he'll look at me all wounded for drinking without him. 

anyway it's a very cool bar away from all the other mission hot spots, you have to cross some every empty streets to get here from the main mission drag. it's right by a fire department so i felt pretty safe. but i wouldn't walk here by yourselves ladies. 

the drinks were for real and well priced. i think my manhattan was $8 and it was perfect. really perfect. and big. they don't mess around. the venue is cool, it feels old, and there are some entertaining naked lady paintings hanging around. it reminds me of an old bordello parlor, or speakeasy. my friend said it's the oldest bar in the city, which, if that's true, makes it even better. 

they have a dj on the weekends--altho i'm not sure they need one since their music selection is pretty cool without him. 

oh, also there is a giant dog here. like big enuf to put your head in his mouth. but he moves very slowly and doesn't seem to be interested in people. so no worries.
author: rachel p.

description: I went here on a Monday night which happened to be dollar blue ribbon night as well.. They had this awesome dj? but not really but i will go with dj.. who was playing old school songs on an old school record player.. "Sylvia! yes Mickey, How do you call your lover boy? Come here lover boy!" haha a star right there for playing that song! another big star for giving out free peanuts! who doesn't love peanuts and beer? This is a dog friendly bar which is super cool so star... The crowd is not something you are going to see in the marina.. just laid back chill have a good timer goers.. i liked it.. at one point i was sitting next to a locked piano (lame! i wanted to play with it) and happened to look up and what do i see.. tits.. there are a few naked pictures in this bar which is silly and very fitting for the place... the bartenders were on it.. this place was super packed when i was here and they were still coming around and taking beers from our table.. This is a fun place where you can mingle with everyone in there even if you only came with one other person.. will i be coming back... are you kidding.. they have free peanuts! im in!
author: Ashley M.

description: My friend asks us to meet here every year for his birthday drinks and I love him for it!  Cozy + comfy.  Easy parking.  Great service.  Nice hum of folks having a good time.
author: Lily C.

description: A very cool and chill bar that serves a great happy hour (until 7 m-th and 6 f) with shelled peanuts!  The crowds is cool and contains a lot of english dudes!
author: Julie R.

description: Pretty, hidden-away, with a good crowd.  A great place if you are or are looking for creative types and intellectuals of the single, 20- and 30-something variety.  Not a great place to get your mack on, but if you are polite, you might make friends.
author: Greg W.

description:
our first time at homestead was nice, the place looks cool inside and the bartender ladies are super nice. also there are peanut, and i like peanuts.

the selection is good, although the prices are a little to high for something of the main drags but not too steep. i'll be coming back
author: Jared Z.

description: I needed to have a drink and dragged my friend along.  We sat there and cried about our friend who was in the hospital.  Homestead gave me that peace and quiet that I needed to have with a good glass of wine.  I liked the dim lighting and the extra detail in decor.
author: Leslie U.

description: Went here for the first time recently. Really liked the ambiance and the bar tender was super nice. Good cozy chill bar.
author: Adrienne G.

description: Free peanuts?  Dude, why don't ALL bars serve free peanuts??  Friendly bartender, lots of hipster folks who seemed not too wrapped up in themselves and sub $5 draft beers - i'm a fan.
author: Matt S.

description: Had a great time here St Pattys day, great crowd (ha, it was mostly my friends...duh) and tasty beverages! Too bad its a lil outta the way for me or Id go there more often!
author: Inome C.

description: A most excellent place for a beverage.  No bridge and tunnel people.  Excellent decor.  Snooty, but good jukebox.
author: Jim B.

description: Pretty much my home away from home, not only due to proximity, but quality. I love a place that has friendly staff, a fine beverage selection, a good jukebox, takes credit cards, has a fireplace, and is usually quiet enough to talk to my friends without yelling into each other's ears.
author: Evan R.

description: The interior is so bomb - and while I know it's not your first priority to be staring at the walls in a bar, it's worth noting that whoever the designer is gets points for creating such an intimate, classy, but laid-back atmosphere. I ended up having a ginger beer instead of an alcoholic drink, but the bartender understood my sinus plight and gleefully served my pal (that isn't an understatement either...this chick was seriously happy, it was cute). It's a brisk walk from the bustle of Mission Street, but totally worth it to have a more piece and quiet time in a solid bar.
author: Jenz y.

description: Decent beer selection and bartenders take pride in their mixed drinks, but stick to the basics: bloody mary, margarita, etc.  This an restored century old sort of joint with peanuts shell strewn about the floor.
author: Christopher K.

description: Fuck yeah dude. Excellent. Cool bartenders, nice people, really excellent jukebox, cozy place. I was concerned when this place reopened after it was Dylan's for a number of years that it would be too "gentrified". But -  my worries were unfounded - it's totally cool. Get's a little too crowded occasionally, but even then the atmosphere is still cool, never aggro.
author: chris n.

description: this will go down in history as one of my most favorite places to chill. peanut shells on the floor! Bartenders have been different each time I went, and never was I let down. GREAT SERVICE with wit and a great Jukebox, I spent like $7 just on songs! I love this place.
author: messy b.

description: Marionnettiste. liminal. aesthete. maybe pseudo-intellectual. Yeah those words came to mind as well as raging douchebag when we went to homestead the other night. The bartenders there must have iron clad armor when having to deal with people who should be wearing baby diapers and playing with pieces of purple felt instead of digging into their wallets for identification. We just wanted a drink and had to endure these two assholes spittle as it splashed all over us while they were in the midst of some unnecessary pontification about how they are old enough to drink. Their names aren't important because their significance to the human race is minimal except to mention that our wonderful and overly patient bartender who serves up mean drinks and should of been given a purple star after "soaking" in the worst of mankind. I guess they ran out of Rohypnol. Keep up the good work Homestead! Love ya!!
author: Kevin C.

description: Seemed like a good neighborhood watering hole. Type of place which seems off the beaten track to all but those who live in the 'hood. I had the impression that everyone knew each other. I wish there was a place like this in my neighborhood. It was packed when we were there (a Saturday), and I'd probably have enjoyed it more if it'd been 10% less crowded, but so what? I'd go there again in a heartbeat.
author: Steve R.

description: i hosted a homecoming happy hour here and it's gem.  i actually hosted a farewll party at the same locale when it was dylan's.  i like all the new refurbishments.  still dog friendly with treats at the bar.  mondays are $2 pbr nights!!  staff is uber friendly and the clietele is chill.  plenty of parking on the street.  seriously, what's not to like?
author: Sharlene C.

description: grab beers here after climbing Mission Cliffs great nudies on the wall and peanut shells on the floor. Occasionally good food on the corner too pizza or tamales.
author: evan n.

description: A nice relaxing neighborhood bar.  The bartenders are friendly and it's an inviting atmosphere.  Keeping it simple in style.
author: michelle m.

description:
First time I went here was for an afterparty with Devo. Fascinated by the decor, too drunk to remember much else.

Second time was fun...the peanuts are addictive and the decor was still fascinating. The bartender seemed like she was in a permanent happy mood, which was contagious and I drank like a fish. 
I went back the night after and a different bartender was there. The mood of the entire bar seemed changed. Quieter, almost surly.

Overall, it feels like a v. cool, not your traditional hipster bar, more like a neighbourhood gaff. If I lived in the city, I'd probably venture there more frequently.
author: Emma G.

description: I can really feel the coolness and history in this Pub.  Be prepared to become very relaxed and at ease as soon as you walk in the door.
author: rick n.

description:
Nice chill place in the Mission.

I was actually able to convince my wife to go drinking with me on a Sunday afternoon and she liked the Homestead enough to have three, that's right, count 'em, three Lillets while we were there.  She even posted a comment about the Homestead on the Facebook.  Now, if that isn't a ringing endorsement, then I'm not sure what is.

Now, while it is also true that she will often have 4 margaritas at Zeitgeist on a Sunday afternoon - she has NEVER posted on Facebook about it and usually tells me how much she hates being at Zeitgeist until around the 3rd Margarita.  That's when the tequila starts making her mad at me instead of Zeitgeist.

Anyway, the point is, that I now have a sure place to get my wife drunk on a Sunday afternoon.  Thank you Homestead.
author: Jamie B.

description:
Great decor and good selection of libations.  Anyplace that encourages its patrons to throw peanut shells on the ground gets a gold star in my book.
Added bonuses: fireplace, dog fights and a decent jukebox.
author: pauline e.

description: love this place!  peanuts / miller highlife!  what else is there!  seriously!  great atmosphere, and cool art work!
author: Brett H.

description: chill, unpretentious bar.  i was noticing their neat golden antique looking cash register.  they have champagne splits!  easy parking
author: X X.

description: Lovee this place. Peanuts on the ground... fast, efficient bartenders, and a great jukebox! What better than that. The decor is super nice, and anybody can feel comfy here late at night. And again... peanuts!
author: Alexandra a.

description: killer.  if my grandpa were still alive, we would go here and drink wiskey and talk about, um, Ireland, or something.
author: Bernard W.

description: nothing i can say bad about this, my newest favoritest neighborhood bar.  just don't come here so i can keep on loving it like i love it now.  love it so good.
author: Sharon M.

description: decor + awesome whiskey selection + friendly staff = great place
author: James R.

description: Cool bar. Was sort of ignored the first few times I/we went in, but the bartenders seem to have warmed up. Nothing wrong with it and you can drop your shells on the floor.
author: Gym W.

description: this place is hipster paradise!  i mean that in the nicest way possible of course.  but i have never seen so many funky dressed people all in one place in my life - loved it.  and the drinks - good and cheap, just the way i like them!  this bar is really cool - i love the decor, with the old wallpaper and the tin ceilings.  fun music too - it was like being in another time.  i would definitely frequent this bar when i am in the mission... really great.
author: Carolyn B.

description: great style, plenty of room for one or a group of 10- good drinks, a little pricey but I still had a couple or four...I dig the esthetics too...
author: Brian G.

description: ...as my coworkers are honestly averse to any place that is outside of a 7 block radius of our job...sometimes we stumble into this bar after work (ps.we're teachers) for a cocktail.  forget the sandwich method i'll start with the bad news. the location is honestly about 35 steps from our school, and c'mon, noone wants to see their teachers rollin into/out of  a bar.  so, i know i know...that's not the homestead's bad.  all that aside, i cant tell you the size of the smile that rings out across my face when the bartender serves me a nice whiskey & ginger with the sweetest, juiciest,   blood orange floating inside.  bliss is an understatement. despite the fact that i wish they had a stealth mode that would black out the windows...i cant deny the fact that i've come to enjoy this spot a great deal.  oh and you get to throw peanuts on the floor.  you cant beat that with a bat.
author: hollie m.

description: We  thought a phoenix would rise from the ashes of our once beloved welsh bar dylan's but lo and behold I am not a cowboy! Surrounded by somber felt-covered walls, our drinks were served to us and taken swiftly away before 2:00 am. The bartenders rudely pushed us out before we had time to finish our drinks.  Compared to the lively  warmth of dylan's with its colorful welsh paraphernalia, great jukebox,  and local characters this bar was ice-cold with behavior to match. We will not be going back. Clearly, home is not "in the stead".
author: derrick s.

description: I like this bar because they allow dogs. There usually aren't too many dogs, and they usually don't run around, but I like bars that allow dogs. I haven't seen any snarling pit bulls here. Usually timid smaller dogs and sleeping large dogs.The jukebox is okay, and on some Mondays sometimes there is some dude who oozes hipster cool who comes in with a 78 turntable and plays old 78s and they are usually really good and it is pretty fucking cool. not like that horrible music that eminates from Pink when I walk by it. Once in a while someone lumbers in and buys drinks for the whole bar which is pretty fucking cool, too. They sell pitchers of beer and peanuts that you can throw the shells onto the floor like you are on a farm or something. It is on the tamale lady's rotation, but I don't know the exact time because I never order them because I usually have already eaten. Beer selection is pretty good, not Monk's table good but bar good.  And they keep their Borax soap dispenser filled with that Borax powder.
author: Surly V.
